<DL compact>
<DT style='margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(1)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> With respect to 74&nbsp;Centers, the underlying land controlled by the Company is owned in fee entirely by the Company, or, in the case of jointly-owned Centers, by the joint
venture property partnership or limited liability company. With respect to the remaining Centers, the underlying land controlled by the Company is owned by third parties and leased to the Company, the
property partnership or the limited liability company pursuant to long-term ground leases. Under the terms of a typical ground lease, the Company, the property partnership or the limited
liability company pays rent for the use of the land and is generally responsible for all costs and expenses associated with the building and improvements. In some cases, the Company, the property
partnership or the limited liability company has an option or right of first refusal to purchase the land. The termination dates of the ground leases range from 2013 to&nbsp;2132.
<BR><BR> </I></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(2)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> Includes GLA attributable to Anchors (whether owned or non-owned) and Mall and Freestanding Stores as of December&nbsp;31,&nbsp;2006.
<BR><BR> </I></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(3)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> Sales are based on reports by retailers leasing Mall and Freestanding Stores for the twelve months ending December&nbsp;31, 2006 for tenants which have occupied such
stores for a
minimum of 12&nbsp;months. Sales per square&nbsp;foot are based on tenants 10,000&nbsp;square&nbsp;feet and under, excluding theaters.
<BR><BR> </I></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(4)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> Portions of the land on which the Center is situated are subject to one or more ground&nbsp;leases.
<BR><BR> </I></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(5)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> These properties have a vacant Anchor location. The Company is contemplating various replacement tenant and/or redevelopment opportunities for these vacant sites.
</I></FONT></DD></DL>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>26</FONT> <FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Macerich Company</I></FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=8,SEQ=28,EFW="2175451",CP="THE MACERICH COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=499715,FOLIO='26',FILE='DISK132:[07BHL4.07BHL1004]DE1004A.;46',USER='KSOLTER',CD='26-FEB-2007;22:14' -->
<A NAME="page_de1004_1_27"> </A>
<DL compact>
<DT style='margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(6)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> NRCD Equity Partners, Inc., acquired Lord&nbsp;&amp; Taylor from Federated Department Stores, Inc. in a transaction completed in October&nbsp;2006.
<BR><BR> </I></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(7)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> Burlington Coat Factory is scheduled to open a 74,047&nbsp;square&nbsp;foot store at Green Tree Mall in March&nbsp;2007.
<BR><BR> </I></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(8)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> Copeland Sports assigned their lease at Valley River Center to Sports Authority in January 2007 which subsequently closed. Sports Authority is scheduled to reopen in
May&nbsp;2007.
<BR><BR> </I></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(9)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> The Company's ownership interest in this table reflects its legal ownership interest but may not reflect its economic interest since each joint venture has various
agreements
regarding cash flow, profits and losses, allocations, capital requirements and other matters.
<BR><BR> </I></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(10)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> La Curacao is scheduled to open a 164,656&nbsp;square&nbsp;foot store at Desert Sky Mall in October&nbsp;2007.
<BR><BR> </I></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(11)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> Barneys New&nbsp;York opened a 81,398&nbsp;square&nbsp;foot store at North Park Center in September&nbsp;2006.
<BR><BR> </I></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(12)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> The office portion of this mixed-use development does not have retail&nbsp;sales.
<BR><BR> </I></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(13)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> Kohl's purchased the 76,145 square foot Mervyn's building at Kitsap Mall from Sun Capital, Inc. in March&nbsp;2006. Kohl's is scheduled to open in
October&nbsp;2007.
<BR><BR> </I></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(14)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> Dick's Sporting Goods is scheduled to open a 90,000&nbsp;square&nbsp;foot store at Washington Square in March&nbsp;2008.
<BR><BR> </I></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(15)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> The former Montgomery Wards building at Southridge Mall was demolished in April&nbsp;2006.
<BR><BR> </I></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(16)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> Wal-Mart purchased the leasehold interest from Burlington Coat Factory at Village Crossroads.
<BR><BR> </I></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(17)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> Home Depot opened a new 141,000&nbsp;square&nbsp;foot store at Twenty Ninth Street in January&nbsp;2006.
<BR><BR> </I></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(18)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> Tenant spaces have been intentionally held off the market and remain vacant because of major development or redevelopment plans. As a result, the Company believes
the percentage of
mall and freestanding GLA leased and the sales per square&nbsp;foot at these major redevelopment properties is not meaningful&nbsp;data.  </I></FONT></DD></DL>
<P ALIGN="RIGHT"><FONT SIZE=2><I>The Macerich Company&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>27</FONT></P>

<DL compact>
<DT style='margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(1)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> The mortgage notes payable balances include the unamortized debt premiums (discounts). Debt premiums (discounts) represent the excess of the fair value of debt over the
principal value of debt assumed in various acquisitions. The debt premiums (discounts) are being amortized into interest expense over the term of the related debt, in a manner which approximates the
effective interest method. The annual interest rate in the above tables represent the effective interest rate, including the debt premiums (discounts).  </I></FONT></DD></DL>
<P ALIGN="RIGHT"><FONT SIZE=2><I>The Macerich Company&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>29</FONT></P>

<DL compact>
<DT style='margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(2)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> On August&nbsp;16, 2006, the Company placed a construction note payable on the property for up to $110,000, which bears interest at LIBOR plus a spread of 1.20% to
1.40% depending on certain conditions. The loan matures in August&nbsp;2009, with two one-year extension options. At December&nbsp;31, 2006, the total interest rate was&nbsp;6.75%.
<BR><BR> </I></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(3)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> In addition to monthly principal and interest payments, contingent interest, as defined in the loan agreement, may be due to the extent that 35% of the amount by
which
the property's gross receipts exceeds a base amount. Contingent interest expense recognized by the Company was $576 for the year ended December&nbsp;31,&nbsp;2006.
<BR><BR> </I></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(4)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> On December&nbsp;7, 2006, the Company placed an interest only $100,000 loan that bears interest at 5.44% and matures in January&nbsp;2013. The loan provides for
additional borrowings of up to $72,500 during the one-year period ending December&nbsp;7, 2007, subject to certain conditions.
<BR><BR> </I></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(5)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> The floating rate loan bears interest at LIBOR plus 0.65%. The Company has stepped interest rate cap agreements over the term of the loan that effectively prevent
LIBOR
from exceeding 7.95%. At December&nbsp;31, 2006, the total interest rate was&nbsp;6.0%.
<BR><BR> </I></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(6)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> The floating rate loan bears interest at LIBOR plus 0.88% that matures on August&nbsp;9, 2007 with two one-year extensions through August&nbsp;9, 2009.
The Company has an interest rate cap agreement over the loan term which effectively prevents LIBOR from exceeding 7.12%. At December&nbsp;31, 2006, the total interest rate was&nbsp;6.23%.
<BR><BR> </I></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(7)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> On January&nbsp;6, 2006, the Company modified the loan to reduce the interest rate to LIBOR plus 1.75% with the opportunity for further reduction upon satisfaction
of
certain conditions to LIBOR plus 1.50%. The maturity was extended to August&nbsp;1, 2008 with two extension options of eighteen and twelve months, respectively. At December&nbsp;31, 2006, the
total interest rate was&nbsp;7.08%.
<BR><BR> </I></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(8)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> The loan bore interest at LIBOR plus 2.0% for six months and then converted at January&nbsp;1, 2005 to a fixed rate loan at 4.94%. The effective interest rate over
the
entire term is&nbsp;4.84%.
<BR><BR> </I></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(9)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> Concurrent with the acquisition of the property, the Company placed a $108,000 loan bearing interest at LIBOR plus 1.15% and maturing July&nbsp;1, 2004 with three
consecutive one-year options. $92,000 of the loan was at LIBOR plus 0.7% and $16,000 was at LIBOR plus 3.75%. The Company extended the loan maturity to July&nbsp;2007. The Company paid
off $16,000 of the loan in May&nbsp;2006, and paid off the remaining $92,000 loan balance on February&nbsp;2, 2007. The  </I></FONT></DD></DL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>30</FONT> <FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Macerich Company</I></FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=3,SEQ=32,EFW="2175451",CP="THE MACERICH COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=862606,FOLIO='30',FILE='DISK132:[07BHL4.07BHL1004]DG1004A.;23',USER='CMATTI',CD='26-FEB-2007;19:30' -->
<A NAME="page_dg1004_1_31"> </A>
<UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=1><I> Company had an interest rate cap agreement over the loan term which effectively prevented LIBOR from exceeding 7.10%. At December&nbsp;31, 2006, the total interest rate was&nbsp;6.05%.  </I></FONT></P>

</UL>
<DL compact>
<DT style='margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(10)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> On February&nbsp;15, 2006, the Company paid off the existing $32,250 floating rate loan that bore interest at LIBOR plus 1.65% and replaced it with a $50,000
floating rate loan that bears interest at LIBOR plus 0.85% and matures in February&nbsp;2010. There is an interest rate cap agreement on the new loan which effectively prevents LIBOR from exceeding
6.65%. At December&nbsp;31, 2006, the total interest rate was&nbsp;6.23%.
<BR><BR> </I></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(11)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> This loan was paid off in full on January&nbsp;2, 2007.
<BR><BR> </I></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(12)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> On November&nbsp;14, 2006, the Company paid off the existing $35,280 floating rate loan and replaced it with a $60,000 fixed rate loan that bears interest at 5.78%
and matures in December&nbsp;2011.
<BR><BR> </I></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(13)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> Northwestern Mutual Life ("NML") is the lender for 50% of the loan. The funds advanced by NML are considered related party debt as they are a joint venture partner
with the Company in Broadway&nbsp;Plaza.
<BR><BR> </I></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(14)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> On April&nbsp;19, 2006, the Company refinanced the loan on the property. The existing floating rate loan was replaced with an $115,000 loan bearing interest at
5.79%
and maturing on May&nbsp;1,&nbsp;2016.
<BR><BR> </I></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(15)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> On June&nbsp;7, 2006, the Company placed a construction note payable on the property for up to $115,000, which bears interest at LIBOR plus a spread of 1.1% to
1.25%
depending on certain conditions. The loan matures in June&nbsp;2007, with two one-year extension options. At December&nbsp;31, 2006, the total interest rate was&nbsp;6.67%.
<BR><BR> </I></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(16)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> Concurrent with the acquisition of this property, the Company placed a $100,000 loan that bears interest at 5.58% and matures on February&nbsp;16, 2016. On
January&nbsp;23, 2007, the Company exercised an earn-out provision under the loan agreement and borrowed an additional $20,000 at a fixed rate of 5.64%.
<BR><BR> </I></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(17)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> This loan bears interest at LIBOR plus 1.25%, matures on December&nbsp;16, 2007 and has a one-year extension option. At December&nbsp;31, 2006, the
total interest rate was 6.60%.
<BR><BR> </I></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(18)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> This loan bears interest at LIBOR plus 0.69%, matures on October&nbsp;9, 2007, and has three one-year extension options. This floating rate debt is
covered by an interest rate cap agreement over the loan term which effectively prevents LIBOR from exceeding 8.54%. At December&nbsp;31, 2006, the total interest rate was 6.04%.
<BR><BR> </I></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(19)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> This represents a construction loan not to exceed $17,500 and bearing interest at LIBOR plus 1.65%. At December&nbsp;31, 2006, the total interest rate
was&nbsp;7.01%.
<BR><BR> </I></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(20)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> On March&nbsp;1, 2006, the joint venture refinanced the existing loan on the property with a $51.5&nbsp;million floating rate loan bearing interest at LIBOR plus
1.10%. This floating rate debt is covered by an interest rate cap agreement over the loan term which effectively prevents LIBOR from exceeding 7.65%. The loan matures in March&nbsp;2008 and has
three one year extension options. At December&nbsp;31, 2006, the total interest rate was 6.45%.
<BR><BR> </I></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(21)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> On May&nbsp;31, 2006, SDG Macerich Properties,&nbsp;L.P. replaced the existing debt that was collectively collateralized by all the properties held by SDG Macerich
Properties,&nbsp;LP., with mortgage notes payable placed on seven specific properties. The remaining five assets are unencumbered. The new debt includes interest-only loans on Eastland
Mall, Empire Mall, Mesa Mall, Rushmore Mall and Southern Hills Mall that bear interest at 5.79% and fixed rate loans on Granite Run Mall and Valley Mall that bear interest at 5.83%. All of these
loans mature on June&nbsp;1,&nbsp;2016.
<BR><BR> </I></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(22)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> This loan was refinanced on January&nbsp;2, 2007 with an $8,600 fixed rate loan at 5.21% and maturing February&nbsp;1, 2012.
<BR><BR> </I></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(23)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> This represents a construction loan not to exceed $49,472 and bearing interest at LIBOR plus 1.75%. At December&nbsp;31, 2006, the total interest rate
was&nbsp;7.13%.
<BR><BR> </I></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(24)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> On May&nbsp;20, 2006, the joint venture replaced the existing loan with a new $130,000 loan bearing interest at LIBOR plus 0.55% that matures on July&nbsp;1, 2011.
The loan provides for additional borrowings of up to $70,000 during the four year period following the initial funding at a rate of LIBOR plus 0.90%. At December&nbsp;31, 2006, the total interest
rate was&nbsp;5.91%.
<BR><BR> </I></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(25)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> This loan bears interest at LIBOR plus 0.94%, matures on February&nbsp;9, 2008 and has two one-year extension options. The joint venture entered into an
interest rate swap agreement for $112.0&nbsp;million to convert this loan from floating rate debt to fixed at a rate of 3.86%, which effectively limits the interest rate on this loan
to&nbsp;4.80%.
<BR><BR> </I></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(26)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> This loan provides for total funding of up to $37,380, subject to certain conditions, and bears interest at LIBOR plus 3.45% and matures February&nbsp;9, 2008. At
December&nbsp;31, 2006, the total interest rate was 8.74%. The joint venture has two interest rate cap agreements throughout the term, which effectively prevent LIBOR from exceeding 5.25% on
$11,500 of the loan and 7.25% on the remaining $25,880 of the loan.
<BR><BR> </I></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(27)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> The annual debt service represents the payment of principal and interest. In addition, contingent interest, as defined in the loan agreement, is due upon the
occurrence of certain capital events and is equal to 15% of proceeds less the base amount. On December&nbsp;21, 2006, the construction loan on the property converted to a mortgage note payable,
bearing interest at 5.41% and maturing on May&nbsp;10,&nbsp;2012.  </I></FONT></DD></DL>
<P ALIGN="RIGHT"><FONT SIZE=2><I>The Macerich Company&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>31</FONT></P>

total interest rate was&nbsp;8.25%.
<BR><BR> </I></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(29)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> The property had a construction note payable which was not to exceed $28.0&nbsp;million which bore interest at LIBOR plus 2.0%. At December&nbsp;31, 2006, the total
interest rate was&nbsp;7.36%. This debt was refinanced on January&nbsp;30, 2007 with a $45,000 fixed rate loan at 5.33%, maturing February&nbsp;1, 2012.
<BR><BR> </I></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(30)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> On August&nbsp;14, 2006, the joint venture replaced the existing loan on the property with a new $67,500 two-year floating rate loan that bears interest
at LIBOR plus 0.37%. In addition, the joint venture has an interest rate cap agreement that effectively prevents LIBOR from exceeding 8.63% throughout the loan term. At December&nbsp;31, 2006, the
total interest rate was&nbsp;5.72%.
<BR><BR> </I></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(31)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> The loan bears interest at fixed rate of 5.23% and matures on February&nbsp;17, 2014. Through February&nbsp;28, 2006, the loan was interest only and requires
principal plus interest payments thereafter. On March&nbsp;31, 2006, the joint venture earned an interest rebate from the lender of $1,257 for meeting a targeted completion date of an expansion to
the property. As a result of the rebate, the effective rate of interest on the loan was reduced from 4.82% to 4.78% over the remaining loan&nbsp;term.
<BR><BR> </I></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(32)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> On October&nbsp;7, 2004, the joint venture placed an additional mortgage loan on the property totaling $35.0&nbsp;million and bearing interest at LIBOR
plus&nbsp;2.00%. At December&nbsp;31, 2006, the total interest rate was 7.35%.
<BR><BR> </I></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(33)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> On August&nbsp;7, 2006, the joint venture replaced the existing loan on the property with a new $70,000 fixed rate loan that bears interest at 6.41%.

<P><FONT SIZE=1><I> <A NAME="dg1004_item_3._legal_proceedings"> </A>
<A NAME="toc_dg1004_1"> </A>
<BR>    </I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2><B>Item 3. Legal Proceedings    <BR>    </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>None of the Company, the Operating Partnership, the Management Companies or their respective affiliates are currently involved in any material litigation nor, to the Company's
knowledge, is any material litigation currently threatened against such entities or the Centers, other than routine litigation arising in the ordinary course of business, most of which is expected to
be covered by liability insurance. For information about certain environmental matters, see "Business &#151;Environmental Matters." </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="di1004_item_5._market_for_registrant___ite04666"> </A>
<A NAME="toc_di1004_2"> </A>
<BR></FONT><FONT SIZE=2><B>Item 5. Market for Registrant's Common Equity, Related Stockholder Matters and Issuer Purchases of Equity Securities    <BR>    </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>The common stock of the Company is listed and traded on the New&nbsp;York Stock Exchange under the symbol "MAC". The common stock began trading on March&nbsp;10, 1994 at a
price of $19 per share. In 2006, the Company's shares traded at a high of $87.10 and a low of&nbsp;$66.70. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>As
of February&nbsp;16, 2007, there were approximately 965&nbsp;stockholders of record. The following table shows high and low closing prices per share of common stock during each quarter in 2006
and 2005 and dividends/distributions per share of common stock declared and paid by&nbsp;quarter: </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>The Company has outstanding 3,627,131&nbsp;shares of its Series&nbsp;A cumulative convertible redeemable preferred stock ("Series&nbsp;A Preferred Stock"). There is no
established public trading market for the Series&nbsp;A Preferred Stock. The Series&nbsp;A Preferred Stock was issued on February&nbsp;25, 1998. Preferred stock dividends are accrued quarterly
and paid in arrears. The Series&nbsp;A Preferred Stock can be converted on a one for one basis into common stock and will pay a quarterly dividend equal to the greater of $0.46 per share, or the
dividend then payable on a share of common stock. No dividends will be declared or paid on any class of common or other junior stock to the extent that dividends on </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="RIGHT"><FONT SIZE=2><I>The Macerich Company&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>33</FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>The Company's existing financing agreements limit, and any other financing agreements that the Company enters into in the future will likely limit, the Company's ability to pay
cash dividends. Specifically, the Company may pay cash dividends and make other distributions based on a formula derived from Funds from Operations (See&nbsp;"Item&nbsp;7. Management's Discussion
and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations &#151;Funds From Operations") and only if no event of default under the financing agreements has occurred, unless, under certain
circumstances, payment of the distribution is necessary to enable the Company to qualify as a REIT under the Internal Revenue&nbsp;Code. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="di1004_stock_performance_graph"> </A>
<A NAME="toc_di1004_3"> </A>
<BR></FONT><FONT SIZE=2><B>Stock Performance Graph    <BR>    </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>The following graph provides a comparison, from December 31, 2001 through December 31, 2006, of the yearly percentage change in the cumulative total stockholder return (assuming
reinvestment of dividends) of the Company, the Standard &amp; Poor's ("S&amp;P") 500 Index, the S&amp;P&nbsp;Midcap&nbsp;400 Index and the NAREIT All Equity REIT Index (the "NAREIT Index"), an industry index
of publicly-traded REITs (including the Company). The Company is providing the S&amp;P&nbsp;Midcap&nbsp;400 Index since it is now a company within such Index. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>The
graph assumes that the value of the investment in each of the Company's common stock and the indices was $100 at the beginning of the period. The graph further assumes the reinvestment of
dividends. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Upon
written request directed to the Secretary of the Company, the Company will provide any stockholder with a list of the REITs included in the NAREIT Index. The historical information set forth
below is not necessarily indicative of future performance. Data for the NAREIT Index, the S&amp;P&nbsp;500 Index and the S&amp;P&nbsp;Midcap&nbsp;400 Index were provided to the Company by Research Data
Group, Inc. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>34</FONT> <FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Macerich Company</I></FONT></P>

<DL compact>
<DT style='margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(1)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> Included in minimum rents is amortization of above and below market leases of $13.1&nbsp;million, $11.6&nbsp;million, $9.2&nbsp;million, $6.1&nbsp;million and
$1.1&nbsp;million for the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2006, 2005, 2004, 2003 and 2002, respectively.
<BR><BR> </I></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(2)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> Unconsolidated joint ventures include all Centers and entities in which the Company does not have a controlling ownership interest and Macerich Management Company
through
June&nbsp;30, 2003. The Company accounts for the unconsolidated joint ventures using the equity method of accounting. Effective July&nbsp;1, 2003, the Company began to consolidate Macerich
Management Company, in accordance with FIN&nbsp;46. Effective July&nbsp;26, 2002, the Company consolidated the accounts of the Westcor management companies.
<BR><BR> </I></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(3)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> The Company's Taxable REIT Subsidiaries ("TRSs") are subject to corporate level income taxes (See&nbsp;Note&nbsp;19 of the Company's Consolidated Financial
Statements).
<BR><BR> </I></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(4)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> In 2002, the Company adopted SFAS&nbsp;No.&nbsp;144, "Accounting for&nbsp;the Impairment or Disposal of Long-Lived Assets." (See&nbsp;"Item&nbsp;7. Management's
Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations &#151;Statement on Critical Accounting Policies").  </I></FONT>
<BR>

<P><FONT SIZE=1><I> Discontinued operations include the following:  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=1><I> The Company sold Boulder Plaza on March&nbsp;19, 2002 and the results for the period from January&nbsp;1, 2002 to March&nbsp;19, 2002 have been classified as discontinued operations. The sale of
Boulder Plaza resulted in a gain on sale of asset of $13.9&nbsp;million in 2002.  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=1><I> The Company sold its 67% interest in Paradise Village Gateway on January&nbsp;2, 2003 (acquired in July&nbsp;2002), and the loss on sale of $0.2&nbsp;million has been classified as discontinued
operations in 2003.  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=1><I> The Company sold Bristol Center on August&nbsp;4, 2003, and the results for the period January&nbsp;1, 2003 to August&nbsp;4, 2003 and for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2002 has been
classified as discontinued operations. The sale of Bristol Center resulted in a gain on sale of asset of $22.2&nbsp;million in 2003.  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=1><I> The Company sold Westbar on December&nbsp;16, 2004, and the results for the period January&nbsp;1, 2004 to December&nbsp;16, 2004, for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2003 and for the period
July&nbsp;26, 2002 to December&nbsp;31, 2002 have been classified as discontinued operations. The sale of Westbar resulted in a gain on sale of asset of $6.8&nbsp;million.  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=1><I> On January&nbsp;5, 2005, the Company sold Arizona Lifestyle Galleries. The sale of this property resulted in a gain on sale of $0.3&nbsp;million and the impact on the results of operations for the
years ended December&nbsp;31, 2005 and 2004 have been reclassified to discontinued operations. Prior to 2004, this property was accounted for under the equity method of&nbsp;accounting.  </I></FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=1><I> On June&nbsp;9, 2006, the Company sold Scottsdale/101 and the results for the period January&nbsp;1, 2006 to June&nbsp;9, 2006 and for the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2005 and 2004 have been
classified as discontinued operations. Prior to January&nbsp;1, 2004, this property was accounted for under  </I></FONT></P>

</DD></DL>
<P ALIGN="RIGHT"><FONT SIZE=2><I>The Macerich Company&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>37</FONT></P>

<UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=1><I> the equity method of accounting. The sale of Scottsdale/101&nbsp;resulted in a gain on sale of asset, at the Company's pro&nbsp;rata share, of $25.8&nbsp;million.  </I></FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=1><I> The Company sold Park Lane Mall on July&nbsp;13, 2006 and the results for the period January&nbsp;1, 2006 to July&nbsp;13, 2006 and for the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2005, 2004, 2003 and
2002 have been classified as discontinued operations. The sale of Park Lane Mall resulted in a gain on sale of asset of $5.9&nbsp;million.  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=1><I> The Company sold Greeley Mall and Holiday Village Mall in a combined sale on July&nbsp;27, 2006, and the results for the period January&nbsp;1, 2006 to July&nbsp;27, 2006 and the years ended
December&nbsp;31, 2005, 2004, 2003 and 2002 have been classified as discontinued operations. The sale of these properties resulted in a gain on sale of assets of $28.7&nbsp;million.  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=1><I> The Company sold Great Falls Marketplace on August&nbsp;11, 2006, and the results for the period January&nbsp;1, 2006 to August&nbsp;11, 2006 and for the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2005,
2004, 2003 and 2002 have been classified as discontinued operations. The sale of Great Falls Marketplace resulted in a gain on sale of $11.8&nbsp;million.  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=1><I> The Company sold Citadel Mall, Crossroads Mall and Northwest Arkansas Mall in a combined sale on December&nbsp;29, 2006, and the results for the period January&nbsp;1, 2006 to December&nbsp;29,
2006 and the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2005, 2004, 2003, 2002 have been classified as discontinued operations. The sale of these properties resulted in a gain on sale of assets of
$132.7&nbsp;million.  </I></FONT></P>

<DL compact>
<DT style='margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(5)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> "Minority Interest" reflects the ownership interest in the Operating Partnership and other entities not owned by the&nbsp;Company.
<BR><BR> </I></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(6)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> Assumes that all OP Units and Westcor partnership units are converted to common stock on a one-for-one basis. The Westcor partnership units were converted into
OP Units on July&nbsp;27, 2004, which were subsequently redeemed for common stock on October&nbsp;4, 2005. It also assumes the conversion of MACWH,&nbsp;LP common and preferred units to the
extent that they are dilutive to the EPS computation (See&nbsp;Note&nbsp;12</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=1>&#151;</FONT><FONT SIZE=1><I>Acquisitions of the Company's Notes to the Consolidated
Financial Statements).
<BR><BR> </I></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(7)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> Assumes issuance of common stock for in-the-money options and restricted stock calculated using the treasury method in accordance with
SFAS&nbsp;No.&nbsp;128 for&nbsp;all years presented.  </I></FONT></DD></DL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>38</FONT> <FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Macerich Company</I></FONT></P>

<P style='page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=6,SEQ=40,EFW="2175451",CP="THE MACERICH COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=985544,FOLIO='38',FILE='DISK132:[07BHL4.07BHL1004]DI1004A.;41',USER='GKIBBE',CD='27-FEB-2007;12:53' -->
<A NAME="page_di1004_1_39"> </A>
<DL compact>
<DT style='margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(8)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> The Company uses Funds from Operations ("FFO") in addition to net income to report its operating and financial results and considers FFO and FFO &#151;diluted as supplemental
measures for the real estate industry and a supplement to Generally Accepted Accounting Principles
("GAAP") measures. The National Association of Real Estate Investment Trusts ("NAREIT") defines FFO as net income (loss) (computed in accordance with GAAP), excluding gains (or&nbsp;losses) from
extraordinary items and sales of depreciated operating properties, plus real estate related depreciation and amortization and after adjustments for unconsolidated partnerships and joint ventures.
Adjustments for unconsolidated partnerships and joint ventures are calculated to reflect FFO on the same basis. FFO and FFO on a fully diluted basis are useful to investors in comparing operating and
financial results between periods. This is especially true since FFO excludes real estate depreciation and amortization as the Company believes real estate values fluctuate based on market conditions
rather than depreciating in value ratably on a straight-line basis over time. FFO on a fully diluted basis is one of the measures investors find most useful in measuring the dilutive
impact of outstanding convertible securities. FFO does not represent cash flow from operations as defined by GAAP, should not be considered as an alternative to net income as defined by GAAP and is
not indicative of cash available to fund all cash flow needs. FFO as presented may not be comparable to similarly titled measures reported by other real estate investment trusts. For the
reconciliation of FFO and FFO-diluted to net income, see "Item&nbsp;7, Management's Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations &#151;Funds from
Operations."  </I></FONT>
<BR>

<P><FONT SIZE=1><I> The computation of FFO-diluted includes the effect of outstanding common stock options and restricted stock using the treasury method. It also assumes the conversion of MACWH,&nbsp;LP
common and preferred units to the extent that they are dilutive to the FFO computation (See&nbsp;Note&nbsp;12 &#151;"Acquisitions of the Company's Notes to the Consolidated Financial
Statements"). The Company had $125.1&nbsp;million of convertible subordinated debentures (the&nbsp;"Debentures") which matured December&nbsp;15, 2002. The Debentures were dilutive for the year
ended December&nbsp;31, 2002 and were included in the FFO calculation. The Debentures were paid off in full on December&nbsp;13, 2002. On February&nbsp;25, 1998, the Company sold
$100&nbsp;million of its Series&nbsp;A Preferred Stock. On June&nbsp;16, 1998, the Company sold $150&nbsp;million of its Series&nbsp;B Preferred Stock. The Preferred Stock can be converted
on a one-for-one basis for common stock. The Series&nbsp;A and Series&nbsp;B Preferred Stock then outstanding was dilutive to FFO in 2006, 2005, 2004, 2003, 2002 and was
dilutive to net income in 2006 and 2003. All of the Series&nbsp;B Preferred Stock was converted to common stock on September&nbsp;9,&nbsp;2003.</I></FONT></P>

</DD></DL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="dk1004_item_7._management_s_discussio__ite03668"> </A>
<A NAME="toc_dk1004_1"> </A>
<BR></FONT><FONT SIZE=2><B>Item 7. Management's Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of&nbsp;Operations    <BR>    </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>This Annual Report on Form&nbsp;10-K contains or incorporates statements that constitute forward-looking statements. Those statements appear in a number of places
in this Form&nbsp;10-K and&nbsp;include statements regarding, among other matters, the Company's growth, acquisition, redevelopment and development opportunities, the Company's
acquisition and other strategies, regulatory matters pertaining to compliance with governmental regulations and other factors affecting the Company's financial condition or results of operations.
Words such as "expects," "anticipates," "intends," "projects," "predicts," "plans," "believes," "seeks," "estimates," and "should" and variations of these words and similar expressions, are used in
many cases to identify these forward-looking statements. Stockholders are cautioned that any such forward-looking statements are not guarantees of future performance and involve risks, uncertainties
and other factors that may cause actual results, performance or achievements of the Company or industry to vary materially from the Company's future results, performance or achievements, or those of
the industry, expressed or implied in such forward-looking statements. Such factors include the matters described herein under "Item&nbsp;1A. Risk Factors," among others. The Company will not
update any forward-looking information to reflect actual results or changes in the factors affecting the forward-looking information. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="dk1004_management_s_overview_and_summary"> </A>
<A NAME="toc_dk1004_2"> </A>
<BR></FONT><FONT SIZE=2><B>Management's Overview and Summary    <BR>    </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>The Macerich Company (the "Company") is involved in the acquisition, ownership, development, redevelopment, management, and leasing of regional and community shopping centers
located throughout the United&nbsp;States. The Company is the sole general partner of, and owns a majority of the ownership interests in, The Macerich Partnership,&nbsp;L.P., a Delaware limited
partnership (the&nbsp;"Operating Partnership"). As of December&nbsp;31, 2006, the Operating Partnership owned or had an ownership interest in 73&nbsp;regional shopping centers and
18&nbsp;community shopping centers aggregating approximately 76.9&nbsp;million square&nbsp;feet of gross leasable area ("GLA"). These 91&nbsp;regional and community shopping centers are
referred to hereinafter as the "Centers", unless the context otherwise requires. The Company is a self-administered and self-managed real estate investment trust ("REIT") and
conducts all of its operations through the Operating Partnership and the Management Companies. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>The
following discussion is based primarily on the consolidated financial statements of the Company for the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2006, 2005 and 2004. It compares the activity for the year
ended December&nbsp;31, 2006 to results of operations for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2005. Also included is a comparison of the activities for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2005 to the
results for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2004. This information should be read in conjunction with the accompanying consolidated financial statements and notes&nbsp;thereto. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Acquisitions and dispositions:  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>The financial statements reflect the following acquisitions, dispositions and changes in ownership subsequent to the occurrence of each transaction. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>On
January&nbsp;30, 2004, the Company, in a 50/50&nbsp;joint venture with a private investment company, acquired Inland Center, a 1&nbsp;million square&nbsp;foot super-regional mall in San
Bernardino, California. The total purchase price was $63.3&nbsp;million and concurrently with the acquisition, the joint venture placed a $54.0&nbsp;million fixed rate loan on the property. The
Company's share of the remainder of the purchase price was funded by cash and borrowings under the Company's line of&nbsp;credit. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>40</FONT> <FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Macerich Company</I></FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=1,SEQ=42,EFW="2175451",CP="THE MACERICH COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=777060,FOLIO='40',FILE='DISK132:[07BHL4.07BHL1004]DK1004A.;23',USER='CMATTI',CD='26-FEB-2007;19:38' -->
<A NAME="page_dk1004_1_41"> </A>
<BR>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>On
May&nbsp;11, 2004, the Company acquired an ownership interest in NorthPark Center, a 2.0&nbsp;million square&nbsp;foot regional mall in Dallas, Texas. The Company's initial investment in the
property was $30.0&nbsp;million which was funded by borrowings under the Company's line of credit. In addition, the Company assumed a pro&nbsp;rata share of debt of $86.6&nbsp;million and
funded an additional $45.0&nbsp;million post-closing. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>On
July&nbsp;1, 2004, the Company acquired the Mall of Victor Valley in Victorville, California and on July&nbsp;20, 2004, the Company acquired La Cumbre Plaza in Santa Barbara, California. The
Mall of Victor Valley is a 547,611&nbsp;square&nbsp;foot regional mall and La Cumbre Plaza is a 494,553&nbsp;square&nbsp;foot regional mall. The combined total purchase price was
$151.3&nbsp;million. The purchase price for the Mall of Victor Valley included the assumption of an existing fixed rate loan of $54.0&nbsp;million at 5.25% maturing in March, 2008. Concurrent
with the closing of La Cumbre Plaza, a $30.0&nbsp;million floating rate loan was placed on the property with an initial interest rate of 2.29%. The balance of the purchase price was paid in cash
and borrowings from the Company's revolving line of&nbsp;credit. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>On
November&nbsp;16, 2004, the Company acquired Fiesta Mall, a 1&nbsp;million square&nbsp;foot super regional mall in Mesa, Arizona. The total purchase price was $135.2&nbsp;million which was
funded by borrowings under the Company's line of credit. On December&nbsp;2, 2004, the Company placed a ten year $84.0&nbsp;million fixed rate loan at 4.88% on the&nbsp;property. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>On
December&nbsp;16, 2004, the Company sold the Westbar property, a Phoenix area property that consisted of a collection of ground leases, a shopping center, and land for $47.5&nbsp;million. The
sale resulted in a gain on sale of asset of $6.8&nbsp;million. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>On
December&nbsp;30, 2004, the Company purchased the unaffiliated owners' 50% tenants in common interest in Paradise Village Ground Leases, Village Center, Village Crossroads, Village Fair and
Paradise Village Office&nbsp;Park&nbsp;II. All of these assets are located in Phoenix, Arizona. The total purchase price was $50.0&nbsp;million which included the assumption of the unaffiliated
owners' share of debt of $15.2&nbsp;million. The balance of the purchase price was paid in cash and borrowings from the Company's line of credit. Accordingly, the Company now owns 100% of
these&nbsp;assets. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>The
Mall of Victor Valley, La Cumbre Plaza, Fiesta Mall, Paradise Village Ground Leases, Village Center, Village Crossroads, Village Fair and Paradise Village Office&nbsp;Park II are referred to
herein as the "2004 Acquisition Centers." </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>On
January&nbsp;5, 2005, the Company sold Arizona Lifestyle Galleries for $4.3&nbsp;million. The sale resulted in a gain on sale on asset of $0.3&nbsp;million. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>On
January&nbsp;11, 2005, the Company became a 15% owner in a joint venture that acquired Metrocenter Mall, a 1.3&nbsp;million square&nbsp;foot super-regional mall in Phoenix, Arizona. The
total purchase price was $160&nbsp;million and concurrently with the acquisition, the joint venture placed a $112&nbsp;million loan on the property. The Company's share of the purchase price, net
of the debt, was $7.2&nbsp;million which was funded by cash and borrowings under the Company's line of&nbsp;credit. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="RIGHT"><FONT SIZE=2><I>The Macerich Company&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>41</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=2,SEQ=43,EFW="2175451",CP="THE MACERICH COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=322674,FOLIO='41',FILE='DISK132:[07BHL4.07BHL1004]DK1004A.;23',USER='CMATTI',CD='26-FEB-2007;19:38' -->
<A NAME="page_dk1004_1_42"> </A>
<BR>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>On
January&nbsp;21, 2005, the Company formed a 50/50&nbsp;joint venture with a private investment company. The joint venture acquired a 49% interest in Kierland Commons, a
438,721&nbsp;square&nbsp;foot mixed-use center in
Phoenix, Arizona. The joint venture's purchase price for the interest in the Center was $49.0&nbsp;million. The Company assumed its share of the underlying property debt and funded the remainder of
its share of the purchase price by cash and borrowings under the Company's line of&nbsp;credit. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>On
April&nbsp;8, 2005, the Company acquired Ridgmar Mall, a 1.3&nbsp;million square&nbsp;foot super-regional mall in Fort Worth, Texas. The acquisition was completed in a 50/50&nbsp;joint
venture with an affiliate of Walton Street Capital,&nbsp;LLC. The purchase price was $71.1&nbsp;million. Concurrent with the closing, a $57.4&nbsp;million loan bearing interest at a fixed rate
of 6.0725% was placed on the property. The balance of the purchase price was funded by borrowings under the Company's line of&nbsp;credit. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>On
April&nbsp;25, 2005, the Company acquired Wilmorite Properties,&nbsp;Inc., a Delaware corporation ("Wilmorite") and Wilmorite Holdings,&nbsp;L.P., a Delaware limited partnership ("Wilmorite
Holdings"). Wilmorite's portfolio includes interests in 11&nbsp;regional malls and two open-air community shopping centers with 13.4&nbsp;million square&nbsp;feet of space located
in Connecticut, New&nbsp;York, New&nbsp;Jersey, Kentucky and Virginia. The total purchase price was approximately $2.333&nbsp;billion, plus adjustments for working capital, including the
assumption of approximately $877.2&nbsp;million of existing debt with an average interest rate of 6.43% and the issuance of $212.7&nbsp;million of participating convertible preferred units
("PCPUs"), $21.5&nbsp;million of non-participating convertible preferred units and $5.8&nbsp;million of common units in Wilmorite Holdings. The balance of the consideration to the equity holders
of Wilmorite and Wilmorite Holdings was paid in cash, which was provided primarily by a five-year, $450&nbsp;million term loan bearing interest at LIBOR plus 1.50% and a
$650&nbsp;million acquisition loan with a term of up to two years and bearing interest initially at LIBOR plus 1.60%. An affiliate of the Operating Partnership is the general partner and, together
with other affiliates, own approximately 83% of Wilmorite Holdings, with the remaining 17% held by those limited partners of Wilmorite Holdings who elected to receive convertible preferred units or
common units in Wilmorite Holdings rather than cash. The PCPUs can be redeemed, subject to certain conditions, for the portion of the Wilmorite portfolio generally located in the area of Rochester,
New&nbsp;York. The Wilmorite portfolio, exclusive of Tysons Corner Center and Tysons Corner Office (collectively referred herein as "Tysons Center"), are referred to herein as the "2005 Acquisition
Centers." </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>On
February&nbsp;1, 2006, the Company acquired Valley River Center, an 835,694&nbsp;square&nbsp;foot super-regional mall in Eugene, Oregon. The total purchase price was $187.5&nbsp;million
and concurrent with the acquisition, the Company placed a $100.0&nbsp;million ten-year loan on the property. The balance of the purchase price was funded by cash and borrowings under the Company's
line of&nbsp;credit. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>On
June&nbsp;9, 2006, the Company sold Scottsdale/101, a 564,000&nbsp;square&nbsp;foot center in Phoenix, Arizona. The sale price was $117.6&nbsp;million from which $56.0&nbsp;million was
used to payoff the mortgage on the property. The Company's share of the realized gain was $25.8&nbsp;million. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>On
July&nbsp;13, 2006, the Company sold Park Lane Mall, a 370,000&nbsp;square&nbsp;foot center in Reno, Nevada, for $20&nbsp;million resulting in a gain of $5.9&nbsp;million. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>On
July&nbsp;26, 2006, the Company purchased 11&nbsp;department stores located in 10 of its Centers from Federated Department Stores,&nbsp;Inc. for approximately $100.0&nbsp;million. The
purchase price consisted of a $93.0&nbsp;million cash </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>42</FONT> <FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Macerich Company</I></FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='page-break-before:always'></p>

<A NAME="page_dk1004_1_43"> </A>
<BR>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>payment
and a $7.0&nbsp;million future obligation to be paid concurrent with development work by Federated in the future at Company's development properties. The Company's share of the purchase
price was $81.0&nbsp;million and was funded in part from the proceeds of sales of Park Lane Mall, Greeley Mall, Holiday Village and Great Falls Marketplace, and from borrowings under the Company's
line of credit. The balance of the purchase price was paid by the Company's joint venture partners. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>On
July&nbsp;27, 2006, the Company sold Holiday Village, a 498,000&nbsp;square&nbsp;foot center in Great Falls, Montana and Greeley Mall, a 564,000&nbsp;square&nbsp;foot center in Greeley,
Colorado, in a combined sale for $86.8&nbsp;million, resulting in a gain of $28.7&nbsp;million. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>On
August&nbsp;11, 2006, the Company sold Great Falls Marketplace, a 215,000&nbsp;square&nbsp;foot community center in Great Falls, Montana, for $27.5&nbsp;million resulting in a gain of
$11.8&nbsp;million. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>On
December&nbsp;1, 2006, the Company acquired Deptford Mall, a two-level&nbsp;1.0&nbsp;million square&nbsp;foot super-regional mall in Deptford, New&nbsp;Jersey. The total
purchase price of $241.0&nbsp;million was funded by cash and borrowings under the Company's line of credit. On December&nbsp;7, 2006, the Company placed a $100.0&nbsp;million
six-year loan bearing interest at a fixed rate of 5.44% on the property. The loan provides the right, subject to certain conditions, to borrow an additional $72.5&nbsp;million for up to
one-year after the initial funding. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>On
December&nbsp;29, 2006, the Company sold Citadel Mall, a 1,095,000&nbsp;square&nbsp;foot center in Colorado Springs, Colorado, Crossroads Mall, a 1,268,000&nbsp;square&nbsp;foot center
in Oklahoma City, Oklahoma and Northwest Arkansas Mall, a 820,000&nbsp;square&nbsp;foot center in Fayetteville, Arkansas, in a combined sale for $373.8&nbsp;million, resulting in a gain of
$132.7&nbsp;million. The net proceeds were used to pay down the Company's line of credit and pay off the Company's $75.0&nbsp;million loan on Paradise Valley&nbsp;Mall. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Valley
River Center and Deptford Mall are referred to herein as the "2006 Acquisition Centers." </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Redevelopment:  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>The grand opening of the first phase of Twenty Ninth Street, an 817,085&nbsp;square&nbsp;foot shopping district in Boulder, Colorado, took place on October&nbsp;13, 2006.
The balance of the project is scheduled for completion in the Summer 2007. Phase&nbsp;I of the project is 93% leased. Recent store openings include Borders Books, Chipotle Mexican Grill, Helly
Hansen, Lady Foot Locker, lululemon, and Solstice Sunglass Boutique. Wild Oats has also opened their corporate headquarters at this project. Recent lease commitments include Anthropologie, Sephora,
Cantina Laredo, Jamba Juice and North&nbsp;Face. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>On
November&nbsp;1, 2006, the Company received Phoenix City Council approval to add up to five mixed-use towers of up to 165&nbsp;feet at Biltmore Fashion Park. Biltmore Fashion Park
is an established luxury destination for first-to-market, high-end and luxury tenants in the metropolitan Phoenix market. The mixed-use towers are
planned to be built over time based upon&nbsp;demand. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Groundbreaking
took place on February&nbsp;6, 2007 for the 230,000&nbsp;square&nbsp;foot life style expansion at The Oaks in Thousand Oaks, California. Plans also call for the remodeling of
both the interior spaces and the exterior fa&ccedil;ade, and will include a new 138,000&nbsp;square&nbsp;foot Nordstrom scheduled to open at the Center in Fall 2008. New tenants include
Abercrombie Kids, Forever 21, Forth&nbsp;&amp; Towne, Guess?, J.&nbsp;Crew, Iridesse, Planet Funk and Solstice </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="RIGHT"><FONT SIZE=2><I>The Macerich Company&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>43</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=4,SEQ=45,EFW="2175451",CP="THE MACERICH COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=761460,FOLIO='43',FILE='DISK132:[07BHL4.07BHL1004]DK1004A.;23',USER='CMATTI',CD='26-FEB-2007;19:38' -->
<A NAME="page_dk1004_1_44"> </A>
<BR>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Sunglass
Boutique. The combined expansion and renovation of the center is projected to cost approximately $250&nbsp;million and be completed in Fall&nbsp;2008. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>The
first phase of SanTan Village, a $205&nbsp;million regional shopping center under construction in Gilbert, Arizona, is scheduled to open in Fall 2007. The center, currently 85% leased, is an
open-air streetscape that will contain in excess of 1.2&nbsp;million square&nbsp;feet on 120&nbsp;acres. More than 35&nbsp;tenants have committed to date, including Dillard's,
Harkins Theatres, Aeropostale, American Eagle Outfitters, Ann Taylor, Ann Taylor Loft, Apple, Banana Republic, Best Buy, Blue Wasabi, The Body Shop, The Buckle, Charlotte Russe, Chico's, The
Children's Place, Coach, Coldwater Creek, The Disney Store, Eddie Bauer, J. Jill, Lane Bryant/Cacique, lucy, PacSun, Soma by Chico's, Swarovski Crystals, Victoria's Secret, Weisfield's Jewelers,
White House/Black Market and Z&nbsp;Gallerie. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Construction
began in late 2006 on The Promenade at Casa Grande, a $135&nbsp;million, 1.0&nbsp;million-square-foot regional shopping center in Arizona's fastest-growing county.
Located in Casa Grande, Pinal County, the center will be located along the I-10&nbsp;corridor between Phoenix and Tucson. The project is 85% committed, including anchors Target and JC
Penney, and will deliver shopping, dining and entertainment options to a key growth corridor. Phase&nbsp;I of the project, which will include a combination of large-format retailers, specialty
shops and restaurants, is scheduled for completion in Fall 2007. Phase&nbsp;II is comprised of small shops and is scheduled to open in March&nbsp;2008. The Promenade at Casa Grande is 51% owned
by the Company. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>On
January&nbsp;22, 2007, the Fairfax County Board of Supervisors approved plans for a transit-oriented development at Tysons Corner Center in McLean, Virginia. The expansion will add
3.5&nbsp;million square&nbsp;feet of mixed-use space to the existing 2.2&nbsp;million square&nbsp;foot regional shopping center. The project is planned to be built in phases over
the next 10&nbsp;years based on market demand and the expansion of the area's light rail system. Completion of the entitlement process for Phase&nbsp;I, totaling roughly 1.4&nbsp;million
square&nbsp;feet, is anticipated for the first quarter of 2008. The first phase of the project is anticipated to begin development in late&nbsp;2009. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>In
late 2006, plans were announced to bring Barneys New&nbsp;York Department Store to Scottsdale Fashion Square, replacing one of the anchor spaces acquired as a result of the
Federated-May merger. Demolition of the vacant space and adjoining parking structure will begin in 2007, allowing for construction of an additional 100,000&nbsp;square&nbsp;feet of
new shop space and the 65,000-square-foot Barneys New&nbsp;York location. This store is anticipated to open in Fall&nbsp;2009. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Inflation:  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>In the last three years, inflation has not had a significant impact on the Company because of a relatively low inflation rate. Most of the leases at the Centers have rent
adjustments periodically through the lease term. These rent increases are either in fixed increments or based on using an annual multiple of increases in the Consumer Price Index ("CPI"). In
addition, about 6%-13% of the leases expire each year, which enables the Company to replace existing leases with new leases at higher base rents if the rents of the existing leases are
below the then existing market rate. Additionally, historically the majority of the leases required the tenants to pay their pro&nbsp;rata share of operating expenses. In January&nbsp;2005, the
Company began entering into leases that require tenants to pay a stated amount for operating expenses, generally excluding property taxes, regardless of the expenses actually incurred at any center.
This change shifts the burden of cost control to the&nbsp;Company. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>44</FONT> <FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Macerich Company</I></FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=5,SEQ=46,EFW="2175451",CP="THE MACERICH COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=927702,FOLIO='44',FILE='DISK132:[07BHL4.07BHL1004]DK1004A.;23',USER='CMATTI',CD='26-FEB-2007;19:38' -->
<A NAME="page_dk1004_1_45"> </A>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Seasonality:  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>The shopping center industry is seasonal in nature, particularly in the fourth quarter during the holiday season when retailer occupancy and retail sales are typically at their
highest levels. In addition, shopping malls achieve a substantial portion of their specialty (temporary retailer) rents during the holiday season and the majority of percentage rent is recognized in
the fourth quarter. As a result of the above, earnings are generally higher in the fourth&nbsp;quarter. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="dk1004_critical_accounting_policies"> </A>
<A NAME="toc_dk1004_3"> </A>
<BR></FONT><FONT SIZE=2><B>Critical Accounting Policies    <BR>    </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>The preparation of financial statements in conformity with accounting principles generally accepted in the United&nbsp;States of America requires management to make estimates
and assumptions that affect the reported amounts of assets and liabilities and disclosure of contingent assets and liabilities at the date of the financial statements and the reported amounts of
revenues and expenses during the reporting period. Actual results could differ from those estimates. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Some
of these estimates and assumptions include judgments on revenue recognition, estimates for common area maintenance and real estate tax accruals, provisions for uncollectible accounts, impairment
of
long-lived assets, the allocation of purchase price between tangible and intangible assets, and estimates for environmental matters. The Company's significant accounting policies are
described in more detail in Note&nbsp;2 to&nbsp;the Consolidated Financial Statements. However, the following policies are deemed to be&nbsp;critical. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Revenue Recognition  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Minimum rental revenues are recognized on a straight-line basis over the term of the related lease. The difference between the amount of rent due in a year and the
amount recorded as rental income is referred to as the "straight lining of rent adjustment." Currently, 40% of the mall and freestanding leases contain provisions for CPI rent increases periodically
throughout the term of the lease. The Company believes that using an annual multiple of CPI increases, rather than fixed contractual rent increases, results in revenue recognition that more closely
matches the cash revenue from each lease and will provide more consistent rent growth throughout the term of the leases. Percentage rents are recognized when the tenants' specified sales targets have
been met. Estimated recoveries from tenants for real estate taxes, insurance and other shopping center operating expenses are recognized as revenues in the period the applicable expenses
are&nbsp;incurred. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Property  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Costs related to the development, redevelopment, construction and improvement of properties are capitalized. Interest incurred on development, redevelopment and construction
projects is capitalized until construction is substantially complete. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Maintenance
and repairs expenses are charged to operations as incurred. Costs for major replacements and betterments, which includes HVAC equipment, roofs, parking lots, etc., are capitalized and
depreciated over their estimated useful lives. Gains and losses are recognized upon disposal or retirement of the related assets and are reflected in&nbsp;earnings. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="RIGHT"><FONT SIZE=2><I>The Macerich Company&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>45</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=6,SEQ=47,EFW="2175451",CP="THE MACERICH COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=887837,FOLIO='45',FILE='DISK132:[07BHL4.07BHL1004]DK1004B.;22',USER='CMATTI',CD='26-FEB-2007;19:38' -->
<A NAME="page_dk1004_1_46"> </A>
<BR>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Property
is recorded at cost and is depreciated using a straight-line method over the estimated useful lives of the assets as&nbsp;follows: </FONT></P>

<!-- User-specified TAGGED TABLE -->

<TD WIDTH="3%"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="49%" ALIGN="RIGHT"><FONT SIZE=2>5-40&nbsp;years</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR BGCOLOR="White" VALIGN="TOP">
<TD WIDTH="49%"><FONT SIZE=2>Tenant improvements</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="49%" ALIGN="RIGHT"><FONT SIZE=2>5-7&nbsp;years</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR BGCOLOR="#CCEEFF" VALIGN="TOP">
<TD WIDTH="49%"><FONT SIZE=2>Equipment and furnishings</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="49%" ALIGN="RIGHT"><FONT SIZE=2>5-7&nbsp;years</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="TOP">
<TD COLSPAN=3><HR NOSHADE></TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<!-- end of user-specified TAGGED TABLE -->


<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Accounting for Acquisitions  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>The Company accounts for all acquisitions in accordance with Statement of Financial Accounting Standards ("SFAS") No.&nbsp;141, "Business Combinations." The Company will
first determine the value of the land and buildings utilizing an "as if vacant" methodology. The Company will then assign a fair value to any debt assumed at acquisition. The balance of the purchase
price will be allocated to tenant improvements and identifiable intangible assets or liabilities. Tenant improvements represent the tangible assets associated with the existing leases valued on a
fair market value basis at the acquisition date prorated over the remaining lease terms. The tenant improvements are classified as an asset under real estate investments and are depreciated over the
remaining lease terms. Identifiable intangible assets and liabilities relate to the value of in-place operating leases which come in three forms: (i)&nbsp;leasing commissions and legal
costs, which represent the value associated with "cost avoidance" of acquiring in-place leases, such as lease commissions paid under terms generally experienced in the Company's markets;
(ii)&nbsp;value of in-place leases, which represents the estimated loss of revenue and of costs incurred for the period required to lease the "assumed vacant" property to the occupancy
level when purchased; and (iii)&nbsp;above or below market value of in-place leases, which represents the difference between the contractual rents and market rents at the time of the
acquisition, discounted for tenant credit risks. Leasing commissions and legal costs are recorded in deferred charges and other assets and are amortized over the remaining lease terms. The value of
in-place leases are recorded in deferred charges and other assets and amortized over the remaining lease terms plus an estimate of renewal of the acquired leases. Above or below market
leases are classified in deferred charges and other assets or in other accrued liabilities, depending on whether the contractual terms are above or below market, and the asset or liability is
amortized to rental revenue over the remaining terms of the&nbsp;leases. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>When
the Company acquires real estate properties, the Company allocates the purchase price to the components of these acquisitions using relative fair values computed using its estimates and
assumptions. These estimates and assumptions impact the amount of costs allocated between various components as well as the amount of
costs assigned to individual properties in multiple property acquisitions. These allocations also impact depreciation expense and gains or loses recorded on future sales of&nbsp;properties.
Generally, the Company engages a valuation firm to assist with these allocations. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Asset Impairment  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>The Company assesses whether there has been impairment in the value of its long-lived assets by considering factors such as expected future operating income, trends
and prospects, as well as the effects of demand, competition and other economic factors. Such factors include the tenant's ability to perform their duties and pay rent under the terms of the leases.
The Company may recognize impairment losses if the cash flows are not sufficient to cover its investment. Such a loss would be determined as the difference between the carrying value and the fair
value of a&nbsp;center. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>46</FONT> <FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Macerich Company</I></FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=7,SEQ=48,EFW="2175451",CP="THE MACERICH COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=393959,FOLIO='46',FILE='DISK132:[07BHL4.07BHL1004]DK1004B.;22',USER='CMATTI',CD='26-FEB-2007;19:38' -->
<A NAME="page_dk1004_1_47"> </A>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Deferred Charges  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Costs relating to obtaining tenant leases are deferred and amortized over the initial term of the agreement using the straight-line method. Costs relating to
financing of shopping center properties are deferred and amortized over the life of the related loan using the straight-line method, which approximates the effective interest method.
In-place lease values are amortized over the remaining lease term plus an estimate of renewal. Leasing commissions and legal costs are amortized on a straight-line basis over
the individual remaining lease years. The ranges of the terms of the agreements are as&nbsp;follows: </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I> <A NAME="dk1004_results_of_operations"> </A>
<A NAME="toc_dk1004_4"> </A>
<BR>    </I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2><B>Results of Operations    <BR>    </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Many of the variations in the results of operations, discussed below, occurred due to the transactions described above including the 2006 Acquisition Centers, 2005 Acquisition
Centers, 2004 Acquisition Centers and Redevelopment Centers. For the comparison of the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2006 to the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2005, "Same Centers" include all
consolidated Centers, excluding 2006 Acquisition Centers, 2005 Acquisition Centers and Redevelopment Centers. For the comparison of the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2005 to the year ended
December&nbsp;31, 2004, "Same Centers" include all consolidated Centers, except the 2005 Acquisition Centers, 2004 Acquisition Centers and Redevelopment Centers. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>For
the comparison of the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2006 to the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2005, "Redevelopment Centers" include Twenty Ninth Street, Santa Monica Place and Westside
Pavilion. For the comparison of year ended December&nbsp;31, 2005 to the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2004, "Redevelopment Centers" include La Encantada, Twenty-Ninth Street, Santa Monica Place
and Queens&nbsp;Center. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>For
comparison of the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2006 to the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2005, Kierland Commons, Metrocenter Mall, Ridgmar Mall and Tysons Center are referred to herein as the
"Joint Venture Acquisition Centers." For the comparison of the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2005 to the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2004, Biltmore Fashion Square, Inland Center and NorthPark
Center are also included in the "Joint Venture Acquisition Centers". Unconsolidated joint ventures are reflected using the equity method of accounting. The Company's pro&nbsp;rata share of the
results from these Centers is reflected in the results of operations in the income statement line item entitled "Equity in income from unconsolidated joint ventures." </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="dk1004_comparison_of_years_ended_december_31,_2006_and_2005"> </A>
<A NAME="toc_dk1004_5"> </A>
<BR></FONT><FONT SIZE=2><B>Comparison of Years Ended December&nbsp;31, 2006 and 2005    <BR>    </B></FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Revenues  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Minimum and percentage rents (collectively referred to as "rental revenue") increased by $65.8&nbsp;million or 14.7% from 2005 to 2006. Approximately $43.5&nbsp;million of
the increase in rental revenue related to the 2005 Acquisition Centers, $11.9&nbsp;million was related to the 2006 Acquisition Centers and $9.9&nbsp;million was related to the Same Centers due in
part to an increase in lease termination income of $7.2&nbsp;million compared to 2005 at the Same Centers. These increases are offset in part by a decrease in rental revenue of $0.5&nbsp;million
at the Redevelopment Centers. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="RIGHT"><FONT SIZE=2><I>The Macerich Company&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>47</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='page-break-before:always'></p>

<A NAME="page_dk1004_1_48"> </A>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>The
amount of straight-lined rents, included in rental revenue, was $7.8&nbsp;million in 2006 compared to $6.7&nbsp;million in 2005. This increase is primarily due to the 2006 Acquisition Centers. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>The
amortization of above and below market leases, which is recorded in rental revenue, increased to $13.1&nbsp;million in 2006 from $11.6&nbsp;million in 2005. The increase in amortization is
primarily due to the 2005 Acquisition Centers and 2006 Acquisition Centers. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Tenant
recoveries increased $39.7&nbsp;million or 18.5% from 2005 to 2006. Approximately $23.0&nbsp;million of the increase in tenant recoveries related to the 2005 Acquisition Centers,
$5.1&nbsp;million related to the 2006 Acquisition Centers and $12.4&nbsp;million related to the Same Centers due to an increase in recoverable shopping center expenses. The increase in tenant
recoveries was offset in part by a decrease of $0.9&nbsp;million at the Redevelopment Centers. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Management Companies' Revenues  </I></FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>Management Companies' revenues increased by $5.3&nbsp;million from 2005 to 2006, primarily due to increased management fees received from the Joint Venture Acquisition
Centers, third party management contracts and increased development fees from joint&nbsp;ventures. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Shopping Center and Operating Expenses  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Shopping center and operating expenses increased $38.2&nbsp;million or 17.1% from 2005 to 2006. Approximately $25.6&nbsp;million of the increase in shopping center and
operating expenses related to the 2005 Acquisition Centers, $5.0&nbsp;million related to the 2006 Acquisition Centers and $8.0&nbsp;million related to the Same Centers offset in part by a
$0.5&nbsp;million decrease at the Redevelopment Centers. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Management Companies' Operating Expenses  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Management Companies' operating expenses increased to $56.7&nbsp;million in 2006 from $52.8&nbsp;million in 2005, primarily as a result of the additional costs of managing
the Joint Venture Acquisition Centers and third party managed properties. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>REIT General and Administrative Expenses  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>REIT general and administrative expenses increased by $1.4&nbsp;million in 2006 from 2005, primarily due to increased share-based compensation expense in&nbsp;2006. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Depreciation and Amortization  </I></FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>Depreciation and amortization increased $31.1&nbsp;million in 2006 from 2005. The increase is primarily attributed to the 2005 Acquisition Centers of $17.8&nbsp;million,
the 2006 Acquisition Centers of $6.2&nbsp;million and the Same Centers of $7.4&nbsp;million. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Interest Expense  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Interest expense increased $37.6&nbsp;million in 2006 from 2005. Approximately $13.8&nbsp;million of the increase relates to the term loan associated with the 2005
Acquisition Centers, $12.4&nbsp;million relates to assumed debt from the 2005 Acquisition Centers, $5.3&nbsp;million relates to the 2006 Acquisition Centers, $13.3&nbsp;million relates to
increased borrowings and higher interest rates under the Company's line of credit, $6.7&nbsp;million relates to higher interest rates on the $250&nbsp;million term loan and approximately
$8.9&nbsp;million relates to increased interest expense due to </FONT></P>

and higher rates on floating rate debt regarding the Same Centers. These increases were offset in part by an approximately $1.3&nbsp;million decrease in interest expense at the

<P><FONT SIZE=2>The equity in income of unconsolidated joint ventures increased $9.7&nbsp;million in 2006 from 2005. Approximately $6.5&nbsp;million of the increase relates to increased
income from the Joint Venture Acquisition Centers, increased net income of $3.3&nbsp;million from the Pacific Premier Retail Trust joint venture due to increased rental revenue and
$4.6&nbsp;million from other joint ventures due to increased rental revenues. This is partly offset by a $4.7&nbsp;million increase in interest expense from the SDG Macerich Properties, L.P.

<P><FONT SIZE=2>The Company recorded a loss from the early extinguishment of debt of $1.8&nbsp;million in 2006 related to the pay off of the $619&nbsp;million acquisition loan on
January&nbsp;19, 2006. In 2005, the Company recorded a loss on early extinguishment of debt of $1.7 relating to the refinancing of the mortgage note payable on Valley View&nbsp;Mall. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Discontinued Operations  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>The increase of $202.1&nbsp;million in discontinued operations relates to the gain on sales of Scottsdale/101, Park Lane Mall, Holiday Village, Greeley Mall, Great Falls
Marketplace, Citadel Mall, Crossroads Mall and Northwest Arkansas Mall in 2006 (See&nbsp;"Management's Overview and Summary &#151;Acquisitions and dispositions"). As result of the sales, the
Company reclassified the results of operations for these properties for 2006 and&nbsp;2005. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Minority Interest in the Operating Partnership  </I></FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>The minority interest in the Operating Partnership represents the 15.8% weighted average interest of the Operating Partnership not owned by the Company during 2006 compared to
the 19.0% not owned by the Company during 2005. The change is primarily due to the stock offering by the Company in January&nbsp;2006. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Funds From Operations  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Primarily as a result of the factors mentioned above, Funds from Operations ("FFO") &#151;Diluted increased 13.7% to $383.1&nbsp;million in 2006 from
$336.8&nbsp;million in 2005. For the reconciliation of FFO and FFO-diluted to net income available to common stockholders, see "Funds from Operations." </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Operating Activities  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Cash flow from operations decreased to $211.9&nbsp;million in 2006 from $235.3&nbsp;million in 2005. The decrease is primarily due to changes in assets and liabilities in
2006 compared to 2005 and due to the results at the Centers as discussed above. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Investing Activities  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Cash used in investing activities decreased to $126.7&nbsp;million in 2006 from $131.9&nbsp;million in 2005. The decrease is primarily attributed to the cash used to
acquire the 2006 Acquisition Centers and increases in development and
redevelopment costs at the Centers. This is offset by $610.6&nbsp;million in proceeds from the sale of assets in 2006 (See&nbsp;"Management's Overview and Summary &#151;Acquisitions and
dispositions"). </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Financing Activities  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="dm1004_comparison_of_years_ended_december_31,_2005_and_2004"> </A>
<A NAME="toc_dm1004_1"> </A>
