<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Revenues  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Rental revenue increased by 44.3% to $447.9&nbsp;million in 2005 from $310.5&nbsp;million in 2004. Approximately $92.9&nbsp;million of the increase relates to the 2005
Acquisition Centers, $21.6&nbsp;million relates to the 2004 Acquisition Centers and $24.0&nbsp;million primarily relates to the Redevelopment Centers. The increase in rental revenue was offset by
a decrease at the Same Centers of $1.1&nbsp;million. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>The
amount of straight-lined rents, included in rental revenue, was $6.7&nbsp;million in 2005 compared to $1.0&nbsp;million in 2004. This increase in straight-lining of rents relates to the 2005
Acquisition Centers and the 2004 Acquisition Centers which is offset by decreases resulting from the Company structuring the majority of its new leases using an annual multiple of CPI increases,
which generally do not require straight-lining treatment. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>The
amortization of above and below market leases, which is recorded in minimum rents, increased to $11.6&nbsp;million in 2005 from $9.2&nbsp;million in 2004. The increase is primarily due to the
2005 Acquisition Centers and the 2004 Acquisition Centers. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Tenant
recoveries increased to $214.8&nbsp;million in 2005 from $145.1&nbsp;million in 2004. Approximately $52.9&nbsp;million of the increase relates to the 2005 Acquisition Centers,
$5.8&nbsp;million relates to the Redevelopment Centers, $9.2&nbsp;million relates to the 2004 Acquisition Centers and $1.8&nbsp;million relates to the Same&nbsp;Centers. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Management
Companies' revenues increased by 21.4% to $26.1&nbsp;million in 2005 from $21.5&nbsp;million in 2004 primarily due to increased management fees received from the 2005 and 2004 Joint
Venture Acquisition Centers and third party management contracts. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Shopping Center and Operating Expenses  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Shopping center and operating expenses increased to $223.9&nbsp;million in 2005 compared to $146.5&nbsp;million in 2004. This increase is a result of $54.9&nbsp;million
of expenses from the 2005 Acquisition Centers, $10.5&nbsp;million from the 2004 Acquisition Centers and $5.6&nbsp;million from the Redevelopment Centers. In addition, there was a
write-off of a contingent compensation liability of $6.4&nbsp;million in&nbsp;2004. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Management Companies' Operating Expenses  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Management Companies' operating expenses increased by 19.7% to $52.8&nbsp;million in 2005 from $44.1&nbsp;million in 2004, primarily due to a higher compensation expense in
2005 compared to&nbsp;2004. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>REIT General and Administrative Expenses  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>REIT general and administrative expenses increased to $12.1&nbsp;million in 2005 from $11.1&nbsp;million in 2004, primarily due to increases in stock-based compensation
expense compared to&nbsp;2004. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>50</FONT> <FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Macerich Company</I></FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=1,SEQ=52,EFW="2175451",CP="THE MACERICH COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=65641,FOLIO='50',FILE='DISK132:[07BHL4.07BHL1004]DM1004A.;57',USER='TOSBORNA',CD='26-FEB-2007;09:02' -->
<A NAME="page_dm1004_1_51"> </A>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Depreciation and Amortization  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Depreciation and amortization increased to $193.1&nbsp;million in 2005 from $128.4&nbsp;million in 2004. Approximately $60.6&nbsp;million relates to the 2005 Acquisition
Centers, $3.0&nbsp;million related to the 2004 Acquisition Centers and $4.1&nbsp;million relates to the Redevelopment Centers. This was offset by a $3.0&nbsp;million decrease relating to the
Same&nbsp;Centers. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Interest Expense  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Interest expense increased to $237.1&nbsp;million in 2005 from $134.5&nbsp;million in 2004. Approximately $26.6&nbsp;million relates to the assumed debt from the 2005
Acquisition Centers, $39.8&nbsp;million relates to the term and acquisition loans for the Wilmorite Acquisition, $19.8&nbsp;million relates to increased borrowings and higher interest rates under
the Company's line of credit, $2.0&nbsp;million relates to the Northridge Center loan which closed on June&nbsp;30, 2004, $5.9&nbsp;million relates to the 2004 Acquisition Centers,
$11.4&nbsp;million related to the Redevelopment Centers and $2.7&nbsp;million relates to an increase in interest rates on floating rate debt at the Same Centers. These increases are offset in
part by a $4.6&nbsp;million decrease related to the payoff of the $250&nbsp;million term loan on July&nbsp;30, 2004. Additionally, capitalized interest was $10.0&nbsp;million in 2005, down
from $8.9&nbsp;million in&nbsp;2004. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Equity in Income from Unconsolidated Joint Ventures  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>The equity in income from unconsolidated joint ventures was $76.3&nbsp;million for 2005, compared to $54.9&nbsp;million in 2004. This primarily relates to increased net
income from the 2005 and 2004 Joint Venture Acquisition Centers of $13.7&nbsp;million. Included in the equity in income from unconsolidated joint ventures is the Company's pro&nbsp;rata share of
straight-line rents, which increased to $4.8&nbsp;million in 2005 from $1.0&nbsp;million in&nbsp;2004. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Gain on Sale of Assets  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>In 2005, a gain of $1.3&nbsp;million was recorded relating to land sales compared to a $0.5&nbsp;million gain on land sales in&nbsp;2004. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Loss on Early Extinguishment of Debt  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>In 2005, the Company recorded a loss from early extinguishment of debt of $1.7&nbsp;million related to the refinancing of the Valley View Mall loan. In 2004, the Company
recorded a loss from early extinguishment of debt of $1.6&nbsp;million related to the payoff of a loan at one of the Redevelopment Centers and the payoff of the $250&nbsp;million term loan on
July&nbsp;30,&nbsp;2004. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Discontinued Operations  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>The gain on sale of $0.3&nbsp;million in 2005 relates primarily to the sale of Arizona Lifestyle Galleries on January&nbsp;5, 2005. In 2004, the gain on sale primarily
related to the $6.8&nbsp;million gain from the sale of the Westbar property on December&nbsp;16, 2004. The decrease in income from discontinued operations relates to the Westbar property. As a
result of sales of properties in 2006, the Company reclassified the results of operations for these properties in 2005 and 2004. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Minority Interest in the Operating Partnership  </I></FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>The minority interest in the Operating Partnership represents the 19.0% weighted average interest of the Operating Partnership not owned by the Company during 2005. This
compares to 19.5% not owned by the Company during&nbsp;2004. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="RIGHT"><FONT SIZE=2><I>The Macerich Company&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>51</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=2,SEQ=53,EFW="2175451",CP="THE MACERICH COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=132650,FOLIO='51',FILE='DISK132:[07BHL4.07BHL1004]DM1004A.;57',USER='TOSBORNA',CD='26-FEB-2007;09:02' -->
<A NAME="page_dm1004_1_52"> </A>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Funds From Operations  </I></FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>Primarily as a result of the factors mentioned above, FFO &#151;Diluted increased 12.6% to $336.8 million in 2005 from $299.2 million in 2004. For the reconciliation of
FFO and FFO &#151;diluted to net income available to common stockholders, see "Funds from Operations." </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Operating Activities  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Cash flow from operations was $235.3&nbsp;million in 2005 compared to $213.2&nbsp;million in 2004. The increase is primarily due to the foregoing results at the Centers and
offset by an increase in working capital. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Investing Activities  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Cash used in investing activities was $131.9&nbsp;million in 2005 compared to $489.8&nbsp;million in 2004. The change resulted primarily from increases in distributions of
capital from unconsolidated joint ventures. This is offset by the joint venture acquisitions of Metrocenter and Kierland Commons, the Company's additional contributions to NorthPark Center and the
decreased development, redevelopment, expansion and renovation of Centers in 2005 compared to 2004 due to completion of the Queens Center and La&nbsp;Encantada projects. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Financing Activities  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Cash flow used in financing activities was $20.3&nbsp;million in 2005 compared to cash flow provided by financing activities of $308.4&nbsp;million in 2004. The 2005
decrease compared to 2004 resulted primarily from fewer refinancings for 2005 than 2004 and increased dividend payments to common stockholders. Additionally, the funding of the Queens construction
loan was $65.7&nbsp;million less in 2005 compared to 2004 due to the substantial completion of the expansion project. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>Liquidity and Capital Resources  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>The Company intends to meet its short term liquidity requirements through cash generated from operations, working capital reserves, property secured borrowings, unsecured
corporate borrowings and borrowings under the revolving line of credit. The Company anticipates that revenues will continue to provide necessary funds for its operating expenses and debt service
requirements, and to pay dividends to stockholders in accordance with REIT requirements. The Company anticipates that cash generated from operations, together with cash on hand, will be adequate to
fund capital expenditures which will not be reimbursed by tenants, other than non-recurring capital expenditures. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>52</FONT> <FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Macerich Company</I></FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='page-break-before:always'></p>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Management expects similar levels to be incurred in future years for tenant allowances and deferred leasing charges and to incur between $400&nbsp;million to
$600&nbsp;million in 2007 for development, redevelopment, expansion and renovations. Capital for major expenditures or major developments and redevelopments has been, and is expected to continue to
be, obtained from equity or debt financings which include borrowings under the Company's line of credit and construction loans. However, many factors impact the Company's ability to access capital,
such as its overall debt level, interest rates, interest coverage ratios and prevailing market conditions. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>The
Company's total outstanding loan indebtedness at December&nbsp;31, 2006 was $6.6&nbsp;billion (including $1.7&nbsp;billion of its pro&nbsp;rata share of joint venture debt). This equated
to a debt to Total Market Capitalization (defined as total debt of the Company, including its pro&nbsp;rata share of joint venture debt, plus aggregate market value of outstanding shares of common
stock, assuming full conversion of OP Units, MACWH,&nbsp;LP units and preferred stock into common stock) ratio of approximately 45.5% at December&nbsp;31, 2006. The majority of the Company's debt
consists of fixed-rate conventional mortgages payable collateralized by individual properties. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>The
Company has filed a shelf registration statement, effective June&nbsp;6, 2002, to sell securities. The shelf registration is for a total of $1.0&nbsp;billion of common stock, common stock
warrant or common stock rights. The
Company sold a total of 15.2&nbsp;million shares of common stock under this shelf registration on November&nbsp;27, 2002. The aggregate offering price of this transaction was approximately
$440.2&nbsp;million, leaving approximately $559.8&nbsp;million available under the shelf registration statement. In addition, the Company filed another shelf registration statement, effective
October&nbsp;27, 2003, to sell up to $300&nbsp;million of preferred stock. On January&nbsp;12, 2006, the Company filed a shelf registration statement registering an unspecified amount of common
stock that it may offer in the&nbsp;future. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>On
January&nbsp;19, 2006, the Company issued 10.9&nbsp;million shares of common stock for net proceeds of $746.5&nbsp;million. The net proceeds were used to pay off the $619.0&nbsp;million
acquisition loan and to pay down the line of credit pending use to pay part of the cash purchase price of Valley River&nbsp;Center. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="RIGHT"><FONT SIZE=2><I>The Macerich Company&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>53</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=4,SEQ=55,EFW="2175451",CP="THE MACERICH COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=776189,FOLIO='53',FILE='DISK132:[07BHL4.07BHL1004]DM1004A.;57',USER='TOSBORNA',CD='26-FEB-2007;09:02' -->
<A NAME="page_dm1004_1_54"> </A>
<BR>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>On
May&nbsp;10, 2006, the SDG Macerich Properties,&nbsp;L.P. joint venture completed a refinancing of its portfolio debt. The joint venture paid off approximately $625.0&nbsp;million of
floating and fixed rate debt with an average interest rate of approximately 6.50%. This debt was replaced by a series of seven new ten-year mortgage notes payable totaling $796.5&nbsp;million with
an average interest rate of 5.81%. The Company's pro&nbsp;rata share of the net proceeds of approximately $85.5&nbsp;million was used to pay down the Company's line of&nbsp;credit. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>The
Company had a $1.0&nbsp;billion revolving line of credit that was set to mature on July&nbsp;30, 2007 plus a one-year extension. The interest rate fluctuated from LIBOR plus 1.15%
to LIBOR plus 1.70% depending on the Company's overall leverage level. On July&nbsp;20, 2006, the Company amended and expanded the revolving line of credit to $1.5&nbsp;billion and extended the
maturity to April&nbsp;25, 2010 with a one-year extension option. The interest rate, after amendment, will fluctuate from LIBOR plus 1.0% to LIBOR plus 1.35% depending on the Company's
overall leverage. In September&nbsp;2006, the Company entered into an interest rate swap agreement that effectively fixed the interest rate on $400.0&nbsp;million of the outstanding balance of
the line of credit at 6.23% until April&nbsp;25, 2011. As of December&nbsp;31, 2006 and 2005, borrowings outstanding were $934.5&nbsp;million and $863.0&nbsp;million at an average interest
rate, net of the $400.0&nbsp;million swapped portion, of 6.60% and 5.93%, respectively. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>On
May&nbsp;13, 2003, the Company issued $250.0&nbsp;million in unsecured notes maturing in May&nbsp;2007 with a one-year extension option bearing interest at LIBOR plus 2.50%. On
April&nbsp;25, 2005, concurrent with the Wilmorite acquisition, the Company modified these unsecured notes and reduced the interest rate to LIBOR plus 1.50%. At December&nbsp;31, 2006 and 2005,
the entire $250.0&nbsp;million of notes were outstanding at an interest rate of 6.94% and 6.0%, respectively. The Company had an interest rate swap agreement which effectively fixed the interest
rate at 4.45% from November&nbsp;2003 to October&nbsp;13,&nbsp;2005. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>On
April&nbsp;25, 2005, concurrent with the Wilmorite acquisition, the Company obtained a five year, $450.0&nbsp;million term loan bearing interest at LIBOR plus 1.50%. In November&nbsp;2005,
the Company entered into an interest rate swap agreement that effectively fixed the interest rate of the $450.0&nbsp;million term loan at 6.30% from December&nbsp;1, 2005 to April&nbsp;15,
2010. At December&nbsp;31, 2006 and 2005 the entire loan was outstanding with an interest rate of&nbsp;6.30%. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>On
December&nbsp;29, 2006, the Company sold Citadel Mall, Crossroads Mall and Northwest Arkansas Mall in a combined sale for $373.8&nbsp;million. The net proceeds from these sales were used to
pay down the Company's line of credit and to pay off the $75.0&nbsp;million loan on Paradise Valley Mall on January&nbsp;2,&nbsp;2007. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>At
December&nbsp;31, 2006, the Company was in compliance with all applicable loan&nbsp;covenants. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>At
December&nbsp;31, 2006, the Company had cash and cash equivalents available of $269.4&nbsp;million. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Off-Balance Sheet Arrangements  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>The Company has an ownership interest in a number of joint ventures as detailed in Note&nbsp;4 to&nbsp;the Company's Consolidated Financial Statements included herein. The
Company accounts for those investments that it does not have a controlling interest or is not the primary beneficiary using the equity method of accounting and those investments are reflected on the
Consolidated Balance Sheets of the Company as "Investments in Unconsolidated Joint Ventures." A pro&nbsp;rata share of the mortgage debt on these properties is shown in Item&nbsp;2.
Properties&#151;Mortgage&nbsp;Debt. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>54</FONT> <FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Macerich Company</I></FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=5,SEQ=56,EFW="2175451",CP="THE MACERICH COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=663867,FOLIO='54',FILE='DISK132:[07BHL4.07BHL1004]DM1004A.;57',USER='TOSBORNA',CD='26-FEB-2007;09:02' -->
<A NAME="page_dm1004_1_55"> </A>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>In
addition, certain joint ventures also have debt that could become recourse debt to the Company or its subsidiaries, in excess of it's pro&nbsp;rata share, should the joint ventures be unable to
discharge the obligations of the related&nbsp;debt. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>The
following reflects the maximum amount of debt principal that could recourse to the Company at December&nbsp;31, 2006 (in&nbsp;thousands): </FONT></P>

</TR>

<!-- end of user-specified TAGGED TABLE -->


<P><FONT SIZE=2>The above amounts decreased $13.1&nbsp;million from December&nbsp;31, 2005. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Additionally,
as of December&nbsp;31, 2006, the Company is contingently liable for $6.1&nbsp;million in letters of credit guaranteeing performance by the Company of certain obligations relating
to the Centers. The Company does not believe that these letters of credit will result in a liability to the&nbsp;Company. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>Funds From Operations  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>The Company uses Funds from Operations ("FFO") in addition to net income to report its operating and financial results and considers FFO and FFO &#151;diluted as
supplemental measures for the real estate industry and a supplement to Generally Accepted Accounting Principles ("GAAP") measures. The National Association of Real Estate Investment Trusts ("NAREIT")
defines FFO as net income (loss) (computed in accordance with GAAP, excluding gains (or&nbsp;losses) from extraordinary items and sales of depreciated operating properties, plus real estate related
depreciation and amortization and after adjustments for unconsolidated partnerships and joint ventures. Adjustments for unconsolidated partnerships and joint ventures are calculated to reflect FFO on
the same basis. FFO and FFO on a fully diluted basis are useful to investors in comparing operating and financial results between periods. This is especially true since FFO excludes real estate
depreciation and amortization as the </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="RIGHT"><FONT SIZE=2><I>The Macerich Company&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>55</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=6,SEQ=57,EFW="2175451",CP="THE MACERICH COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=773883,FOLIO='55',FILE='DISK132:[07BHL4.07BHL1004]DM1004A.;57',USER='TOSBORNA',CD='26-FEB-2007;09:02' -->
<A NAME="page_dm1004_1_56"> </A>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Company
believes real estate values fluctuate based on market conditions rather than depreciating in value ratably on a straight-line basis over time. FFO on a fully diluted basis is one
of the measures investors find most useful in measuring the dilutive impact of outstanding convertible securities. FFO does not represent cash flow from operations as defined by GAAP, should not be
considered as an alternative to net income as defined by GAAP and is not indicative of cash available to fund all cash flow needs. FFO, as presented, may not be comparable to similarly titled
measures reported by other real estate investment trusts. The reconciliation of FFO and FFO &#151;diluted to net income available to common stockholders is provided&nbsp;below. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>The
following reconciles net income available to common stockholders to FFO and FFO &#151;diluted (dollars in&nbsp;thousands): </FONT></P>

<DL compact>
<DT style='margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(1)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> Calculated based upon basic net income as adjusted to reach basic FFO. As of December&nbsp;31, 2006, 2005, 2004, 2003, and 2002, 13.2&nbsp;million, 13.5&nbsp;million,
14.2&nbsp;million, 14.2&nbsp;million and 13.7&nbsp;million of OP Units and Westcor partnership units were outstanding, respectively. The Westcor partnership units were converted to OP Units on
July&nbsp;27, 2004 which were subsequently redeemed for common stock on October&nbsp;4,&nbsp;2005.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=1>
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT SIZE=1>(2)</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I>The computation of FFO &#151;diluted shares outstanding includes the effect of outstanding common stock options and restricted stock using the treasury
method. It also assumes the conversion of MACWH,&nbsp;LP common and preferred units to the extent that it is dilutive to the FFO computation
(See&nbsp;Note&nbsp;12</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=1>&#151;"</FONT><FONT SIZE=1><I>Acquisitions of the Company's Notes to the Consolidated Financial
Statements</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=1>"</FONT><FONT SIZE=1><I>). The convertible debentures were dilutive for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2002 and were included in the FFO calculation. The
convertible debentures were paid off in full on December&nbsp;13, 2002. On February&nbsp;25, 1998, the Company sold $100&nbsp;million of its Series&nbsp;A Preferred Stock. On June&nbsp;16,
1998, the Company sold $150&nbsp;million of its Series&nbsp;B Preferred Stock. On September&nbsp;9, 2003, 5.5&nbsp;million shares of Series&nbsp;B Preferred Stock were converted into common
shares. The preferred stock can be converted on a one-for-one basis for common stock. The then outstanding preferred shares are assumed converted for purposes of 2006, 2005,
2004, 2003 and 2002&nbsp;FFO &#151;diluted as they are dilutive to that calculation.</I></FONT></DD></DL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>56</FONT> <FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Macerich Company</I></FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=7,SEQ=58,EFW="2175451",CP="THE MACERICH COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=883670,FOLIO='56',FILE='DISK132:[07BHL4.07BHL1004]DM1004B.;33',USER='TOSBORNA',CD='26-FEB-2007;09:02' -->
<A NAME="page_dm1004_1_57"> </A>

<P><FONT SIZE=1><A
NAME="dm1004_item_7a._quantitative_and_qual__ite02669"> </A>
<A NAME="toc_dm1004_2"> </A>
<BR></FONT><FONT SIZE=2><B>Item 7A. Quantitative and Qualitative Disclosures About Market Risk    <BR>    </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>The Company's primary market risk exposure is interest rate risk. The Company has managed and will continue to manage interest rate risk by (1)&nbsp;maintaining a ratio of
fixed rate, long-term debt to total debt such that floating rate exposure is kept at an acceptable level, (2)&nbsp;reducing interest rate exposure on certain long-term
floating rate debt through the use of interest rate caps and/or swaps with appropriately matching maturities, (3)&nbsp;using treasury rate locks where appropriate to fix rates on anticipated debt
transactions, and (4)&nbsp;taking advantage of favorable market conditions for long-term debt and/or&nbsp;equity. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>The
following table sets forth information as of December&nbsp;31, 2006 concerning the Company's long term debt obligations, including principal cash flows by scheduled maturity, weighted average
interest rates and estimated fair value ("FV") (dollars in&nbsp;thousands): </FONT></P>

<!-- User-specified TAGGED TABLE -->

<DL compact>
<DT style='margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(1)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> Fixed rate debt includes the $450&nbsp;million floating rate term note and $400&nbsp;million of the line of credit balance. These amounts have effective fixed rates over the
remaining terms due to swap agreements as discussed below.</I></FONT></DD></DL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>The consolidated Centers' total fixed rate debt at December&nbsp;31, 2006 and 2005 was $3.8&nbsp;billion and $3.2&nbsp;billion, respectively. The average interest rate on
fixed rate debt at December&nbsp;31, 2006 and 2005 was 5.99% and 5.70%, respectively. The consolidated Centers' total floating rate debt at December&nbsp;31, 2006 and 2005 was $1.2&nbsp;billion
and $2.2&nbsp;billion, respectively. The average interest rate on floating rate debt at December&nbsp;31, 2006 and 2005 was 6.59% and 5.80%, respectively. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>The
Company's pro&nbsp;rata share of the Joint Venture Centers' fixed rate debt at December&nbsp;31, 2006 and 2005 was $1.5&nbsp;billion and $1.3&nbsp;billion, respectively. The average
interest rate on fixed rate debt at December&nbsp;31, 2006 and 2005 was 5.84% and 6.60%, respectively. The Company's pro&nbsp;rata share of the Joint Venture Centers' floating rate debt at
December&nbsp;31, 2006 and 2005 was $198.4&nbsp;million and $250.3&nbsp;million, respectively. The average interest rate on the floating rate debt was 6.33% and 5.20%, respectively. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>The
Company uses derivative financial instruments in the normal course of business to manage or hedge interest rate risk and records all derivatives on the balance sheet at fair value in accordance
with SFAS&nbsp;No.&nbsp;133, </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="RIGHT"><FONT SIZE=2><I>The Macerich Company&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>57</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>

<DL compact>
<DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2><I>(1)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2><I> Fair value at the Company's ownership percentage.  </I></FONT></DD></DL>
<BR>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Interest rate cap agreements ("Cap") offer protection against floating rates on the notional amount from exceeding the rates noted in the above schedule and interest rate swap
agreements ("Swap") effectively replace a floating rate on the notional amount with a fixed rate as noted&nbsp;above. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>In
addition, the Company has assessed the market risk for its floating rate debt and believes that a 1% increase in interest rates would decrease future earnings and cash flows by approximately
$13.8&nbsp;million per year based on $1.4&nbsp;billion outstanding of floating rate debt at December&nbsp;31,&nbsp;2006. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>The
fair value of the Company's long term debt is estimated based on discounted cash flows at interest rates that management believes reflect the risks associated with long term debt of similar risk
and&nbsp;duration. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>58</FONT> <FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Macerich Company</I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="do1004_item_8._financial_statements_and_supplementary_data"> </A>
<A NAME="toc_do1004_1"> </A>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="do1004_item_9._changes_in_and_disagre__ite03576"> </A>
<A NAME="toc_do1004_2"> </A>
<BR></FONT><FONT SIZE=2><B>Item 9. Changes in and Disagreements with Accountants on Accounting and Financial Disclosure    <BR>    </B></FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>None </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="do1004_item_9a._controls_and_procedures"> </A>
<A NAME="toc_do1004_3"> </A>
<BR></FONT><FONT SIZE=2><B>Item 9A. Controls and Procedures    <BR>    </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Management, including our Chief Executive Officer and Chief Financial Officer, does not expect that its disclosure controls and procedures or its internal controls will prevent
all error and all fraud. A control system, no matter how well conceived and operated, can provide only reasonable, not absolute, assurance that the objectives of the control system are met. Further,
the design of a control system must reflect the fact that there are resource constraints, and the benefits of controls must be considered relative to their costs. Because of the inherent limitations
in all control systems, no evaluation of controls can provide absolute assurance that all control issues and instances of fraud, if any, within the Company have been&nbsp;detected. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>However,
based on their evaluation as of December&nbsp;31, 2006, the Company's Chief Executive Officer and Chief Financial Officer, have concluded that the Company's disclosure controls and
procedures (as&nbsp;defined in Rules&nbsp;13a-15(e) and&nbsp;15d-15(e) under the Securities Exchange Act of 1934, as amended)
were effective to ensure that the information required to be disclosed by the Company in the reports that it files or submits under the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 is (a)&nbsp;recorded,
processed, summarized and reported within the time periods specified in the SEC's rules and forms and (b)&nbsp;accumulated and communicated to the Company's management, including its principal
executive and principal financial officers, or persons performing similar functions, as appropriate to allow timely decisions regarding required disclosure. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Management's Report on Internal Control over Financial Reporting  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>The Company's management is responsible for establishing and maintaining adequate internal control over financial reporting (as&nbsp;defined in
Rule&nbsp;13a-15(f) under the Securities Exchange Act of 1934, as amended). The Company's management assessed the effectiveness of the Company's internal control over financial
reporting as of December&nbsp;31, 2006. In making this assessment, the Company's management used the criteria set forth by the Committee of Sponsoring Organizations of the Treadway Commission
("COSO") in Internal Control &#151;Integrated Framework. The Company's management has concluded that, as of December&nbsp;31, 2006, its internal control over financial reporting is effective
based on these criteria. The Company's independent registered public accounting firm, Deloitte and Touche&nbsp;LLP, has issued an audit report on management's assessment of our internal control
over financial reporting, which is included herein. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="RIGHT"><FONT SIZE=2><I>The Macerich Company&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>59</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=1,SEQ=61,EFW="2175451",CP="THE MACERICH COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=848320,FOLIO='59',FILE='DISK132:[07BHL4.07BHL1004]DO1004A.;19',USER='DCONRAD',CD='24-FEB-2007;02:37' -->
<A NAME="page_do1004_1_60"> </A>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>Report of Independent Registered Public Accounting Firm  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>To
the Board of Directors and Stockholders of<BR>
The Macerich Company<BR>
Santa Monica, California </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>We
have audited management's assessment, included in the accompanying Management's Report on Internal Control over Financial Reporting, that The Macerich Company and its subsidiaries (the "Company")
maintained effective internal control over financial reporting as of December&nbsp;31, 2006, based on criteria established in </FONT><FONT SIZE=2><I>Internal
Control &#151;Integrated Framework</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2> issued by the Committee of Sponsoring Organizations of the Treadway Commission. The Company's management is responsible for
maintaining effective internal control over financial reporting and for its assessment of the effectiveness of internal control over financial reporting. Our responsibility is to express an opinion
on management's assessment and an opinion on the effectiveness of the Company's internal control over financial reporting based on our&nbsp;audit. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>We
conducted our audit in accordance with the standards of the Public Company Accounting Oversight Board (United&nbsp;States). Those standards require that we plan and perform the audit to obtain
reasonable assurance about whether effective internal control over financial reporting was maintained in all material respects. Our audit included obtaining an understanding of internal control over
financial reporting, evaluating management's assessment, testing and evaluating the design and operating effectiveness of internal control, and performing such other procedures as we considered
necessary in the circumstances. We believe that our audit provides a reasonable basis for our&nbsp;opinions. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>A
company's internal control over financial reporting is a process designed by, or under the supervision of, the company's principal executive and principal financial officers, or persons performing
similar functions, and effected by the company's board of directors, management, and other personnel to provide reasonable assurance regarding the reliability of financial reporting and the
preparation of financial statements for external purposes in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles. A company's internal control over financial reporting includes those policies
and procedures that (1)&nbsp;pertain to the maintenance of records that, in reasonable detail, accurately and fairly reflect the transactions and dispositions of the assets of the company;
(2)&nbsp;provide reasonable assurance that transactions are recorded as necessary to permit preparation of financial statements in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles, and that
receipts and expenditures of the company are being made only in accordance with authorizations of management and directors of the company; and (3)&nbsp;provide reasonable assurance regarding
prevention or timely detection of unauthorized acquisition, use, or disposition of the company's assets that could have a material effect on the financial statements. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Because
of the inherent limitations of internal control over financial reporting, including the possibility of collusion or improper management override of controls, material misstatements due to
error or fraud may not be prevented or detected on a timely basis. Also, projections of any evaluation of the effectiveness of the internal control over financial reporting to future periods are
subject to the risk that the controls may become inadequate because of changes in conditions, or that the degree of compliance with the policies or procedures may deteriorate. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>60</FONT> <FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Macerich Company</I></FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=2,SEQ=62,EFW="2175451",CP="THE MACERICH COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=552365,FOLIO='60',FILE='DISK132:[07BHL4.07BHL1004]DO1004A.;19',USER='DCONRAD',CD='24-FEB-2007;02:37' -->
<A NAME="page_do1004_1_61"> </A>
<BR>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>In
our opinion, management's assessment that the Company maintained effective internal control over financial reporting as of December&nbsp;31, 2006, is fairly stated, in all material respects,
based on the criteria established in </FONT><FONT SIZE=2><I>Internal Control &#151;Integrated Framework</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2> issued by the Committee of Sponsoring Organizations of the
Treadway Commission. Also in our opinion, the Company maintained, in all material respects, effective internal control over financial reporting as of December&nbsp;31, 2006, based on the criteria
established in </FONT><FONT SIZE=2><I>Internal Control &#151;Integrated Framework</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2> issued by the Committee of Sponsoring Organizations of the Treadway Commission. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>We
have also audited, in accordance with the standards of the Public Company Accounting Oversight Board (United&nbsp;States), the consolidated financial statements and financial statement schedules
as of and for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2006, of the Company and our report dated February&nbsp;27, 2007 expressed an unqualified opinion on those financial statements and financial
statement schedules. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Deloitte&nbsp;&amp;
Touche&nbsp;LLP<BR>
Los Angeles, California </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>February
27, 2007 </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Equity Compensation Plan Information  </I></FONT></P>

compensation plans which are no longer available for stock awards: the 1994 Eligible Directors' Stock Option Plan (the&nbsp;"Director Plan"), the Amended and Restated 1994 Incentive Plan
(the&nbsp;"1994 Plan") and the 2000 Incentive Plan (the&nbsp;"2000&nbsp;Plan"). </FONT></P>

Company's stockholders. No additional awards will be made under the 2000 Plan. The 2000 Plan generally provided for the grant of options, stock appreciation rights, restricted stock awards, stock
units, stock bonuses and dividend equivalent rights to employees, directors and consultants of the Company or its subsidiaries. The only awards that were granted under the 2000 Plan were stock options
and restricted stock. The stock options granted generally expire not more than 10&nbsp;years after the date of grant and vest in three equal annual installments, commencing on the first anniversary
of the grant date. The restricted stock grants generally vest over three&nbsp;years.</I></FONT></DD></DL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="page_fa1004_1_65"> </A> </FONT></P>

<!-- TOC_END -->

<P><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="fa1004_part_iv"> </A>
<A NAME="toc_fa1004_1"> </A>

<!-- ZEQ.=2,SEQ=68,EFW="2175451",CP="THE MACERICH COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=431030,FOLIO='66',FILE='DISK132:[07BHL4.07BHL1004]FA1004A.;20',USER='DCONRAD',CD='24-FEB-2007;04:20' -->

<P><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="page_fb1004_1_67"> </A> </FONT></P>

<!-- TOC_END -->

<P><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="fb1004_report_of_independent_r__fb102285"> </A>
<A NAME="toc_fb1004_1"> </A>
<BR></FONT><FONT SIZE=2><B>REPORT OF INDEPENDENT REGISTERED PUBLIC ACCOUNTING FIRM    <BR>    </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>To
the Board of Directors and Stockholders of<BR>
The Macerich Company<BR>
Santa Monica, California </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>We
have audited the accompanying consolidated balance sheets of The Macerich Company and subsidiaries (the&nbsp;"Company") as of December&nbsp;31, 2006 and 2005, and the related consolidated
statements of operations, common stockholders' equity, and cash flows for each of the three years in the period ended December&nbsp;31, 2006. Our audits also included the Company's consolidated
financial statement schedules listed in the Index at Item&nbsp;15(a)(4). These consolidated financial statements and consolidated financial statement schedules are the responsibility of the
Company's management. Our responsibility is to express an opinion on these consolidated financial statements and consolidated financial statement schedules based on our audits. We did not audit the
consolidated financial statements or the consolidated financial statements of SDG Macerich Properties,&nbsp;L.P. (the&nbsp;"Partnership"), the Company's investment in which is reflected in the
accompanying consolidated financial statements using the equity method of accounting. The Company's equity of $50,696,000 and $142,102,000 in the Partnership's net assets at December&nbsp;31, 2006
and 2005, respectively, and $11,197,000, $15,537,000 and $16,499,000 in the Partnership's net income for the three years ended December&nbsp;31, 2006 are included in the accompanying consolidated
financial statements. Such financial statements were audited by other auditors whose report has been furnished to us, and our opinion, insofar as it relates to the amounts included for the
Partnership, is based solely on the report of such other&nbsp;auditors. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>We
conducted our audits in accordance with the standards of the Public Company Accounting Oversight Board (United&nbsp;States). Those standards require that we plan and perform the audits to obtain
reasonable assurance about whether the financial statements are free of material misstatement. An audit includes examining, on a test basis, evidence supporting the amounts and disclosures in the
financial statements. An audit also includes assessing the accounting principles used and significant estimates made by management, as well as evaluating the overall financial statement presentation.
We believe that our audits and the report of other auditors provide a reasonable basis for our&nbsp;opinion. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>In
our opinion, based on our audits and the report of other auditors, such 2006, 2005 and 2004 consolidated financial statements present fairly, in all material respects, the financial position of The
Macerich Company and subsidiaries as of December&nbsp;31, 2006 and 2005, and the results of its operations and its cash flows for each of the three years in the period ended December&nbsp;31,
2006, in conformity with accounting principles generally accepted in the United&nbsp;States of America. Also, in our opinion, based on our audits and the report of the other auditors, such
consolidated financial statement schedules, when considered in relation to the basic consolidated financial statements taken as a whole, present fairly, in all material respects, the information set
forth&nbsp;therein. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>We
have also audited, in accordance with the standards of the Public Company Accounting Oversight Board (United&nbsp;States), the effectiveness of the Company's internal control over financial
reporting as of December&nbsp;31, 2006, based on the criteria established in </FONT><FONT SIZE=2><I>Internal Control&#151;Integrated Framework</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2> issued by the Committee
of Sponsoring Organizations of the Treadway Commission and our report dated February&nbsp;27, 2007 expressed an unqualified opinion on management's assessment of the effectiveness of the Company's
internal control over financial reporting and an unqualified opinion on the effectiveness of the Company's internal control over financial&nbsp;reporting. </FONT></P>

<!-- User-specified TAGGED TABLE -->

<TD WIDTH="50%" VALIGN="TOP"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<TD WIDTH="50%" VALIGN="TOP"><FONT SIZE=2><BR>
Deloitte&nbsp;&amp; Touche&nbsp;LLP<BR>
Los Angeles, California</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="50%" VALIGN="TOP"><FONT SIZE=2><BR>
&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<TD WIDTH="50%" VALIGN="TOP"><FONT SIZE=2><BR>
February 27, 2007<BR></FONT>
</TD>

<!-- ZEQ.=1,SEQ=69,EFW="2175451",CP="THE MACERICH COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=691373,FOLIO='67',FILE='DISK132:[07BHL4.07BHL1004]FB1004A.;8',USER='DCONRAD',CD='24-FEB-2007;02:37' -->
<!-- THIS IS THE END OF A COMPOSITION COMPONENT -->

<P><FONT SIZE=2><A

<P><FONT SIZE=2><A

<!-- TOC_END -->

<P><BR><FONT SIZE=2><B>THE MACERICH COMPANY  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B> NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B> (Dollars in thousands, except per share amounts)  </B></FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>1.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Organization:  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>The Macerich Company (the&nbsp;"Company") is involved in the acquisition, ownership, development, redevelopment, management and leasing of regional and community shopping
centers (the&nbsp;"Centers") located throughout the United&nbsp;States. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>The
Company commenced operations effective with the completion of its initial public offering on March&nbsp;16, 1994. As of December&nbsp;31, 2006, the Company is the sole general partner of and
assuming conversion of the preferred units holds an 84% ownership interest in The Macerich Partnership, L.P. (the&nbsp;"Operating Partnership"). The interests in the Operating Partnership are known
as OP Units. OP Units not held by the Company are redeemable, subject to certain restrictions, on a one-for-one basis for the Company's common stock or cash at the Company's
option. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>The
Company was organized to qualify as a real estate investment trust ("REIT") under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, as amended. The 16% limited partnership interest of the Operating Partnership
not owned by the Company is reflected in these financial statements as minority interest. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>The
property management, leasing and redevelopment of the Company's portfolio is provided by the Company's management companies, Macerich Property Management Company,&nbsp;LLC, ("MPMC,&nbsp;LLC")
a single member Delaware limited liability company, Macerich Management Company ("MMC"), a California corporation, Westcor Partners,&nbsp;L.L.C., a single member Arizona limited liability company,
Macerich Westcor Management&nbsp;LLC, a single member Delaware limited liability company and Westcor Partners of Colorado,&nbsp;LLC, a Colorado limited liability company. As part of the Wilmorite
closing (See&nbsp;Note&nbsp;12 &#151;Acquisitions), the Company acquired MACW Mall Management,&nbsp;Inc., a New&nbsp;York corporation and MACW Property Management,&nbsp;LLC, a
New&nbsp;York single member limited liability company. These two management companies are collectively referred to herein as the "Wilmorite Management Companies." The three Westcor management
companies are collectively referred to herein as the "Westcor Management Companies." All seven of the management companies are collectively referred to herein as the "Management Companies." </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>2.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Summary of Significant Accounting Policies:  </B></FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Basis of Presentation:  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>These consolidated financial statements have been prepared in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles ("GAAP") in the United&nbsp;States of America. The
accompanying consolidated financial statements include the accounts of the Company and the Operating Partnership. Investments in entities that are controlled by the Company or meet the definition of
a variable interest entity in which an enterprise absorbs the majority of the entity's expected losses, receives a majority of the entity's expected residual returns, or both, as a result of
ownership, contractual or other financial interests in the entity are consolidated; otherwise they are accounted for under the equity method and are reflected as "Investments in Unconsolidated Joint
Ventures". All intercompany accounts and transactions have been eliminated in the consolidated financial statements. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>72</FONT> <FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Macerich Company</I></FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=1,SEQ=74,EFW="2175451",CP="THE MACERICH COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=897380,FOLIO='72',FILE='DISK132:[07BHL4.07BHL1004]FG1004A.;19',USER='DCONRAD',CD='24-FEB-2007;02:37' -->
<A NAME="page_fg1004_1_73"> </A>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Cash and Cash Equivalents:  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>The Company considers all highly liquid investments with an original maturity of three months or less when purchased to be cash equivalents, for which cost approximates fair
value. Restricted cash includes impounds of property taxes and other capital reserves required under the loan agreements. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Tenant Receivables:  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Included in tenant receivables are allowances for doubtful accounts of $2,700 and $4,588 at December&nbsp;31, 2006 and 2005, respectively. Also included in tenant receivables
are accrued percentage rents of $11,086 and $11,423 at December&nbsp;31, 2006 and 2005, respectively. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Revenues:  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Minimum rental revenues are recognized on a straight-line basis over the term of the related lease. The difference between the amount of rent due in a year and the
amount recorded as rental income is referred to as the "straight-lining of rent adjustment." Rental income was increased by $7,759, $6,703 and $1,037 due to the straight-lining of rent adjustment
during the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2006, 2005 and 2004, respectively. Percentage rents are recognized and accrued when tenants' specified sales targets have been&nbsp;met. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Estimated
recoveries from tenants for real estate taxes, insurance and other shopping center operating expenses are recognized as revenues in the period the applicable expenses are&nbsp;incurred. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>The
Management Companies provide property management, leasing, corporate, development, redevelopment and acquisition services to affiliated and non-affiliated shopping centers. In
consideration for these services, the Management Companies receive monthly management fees generally ranging from 1.5% to 6% of the gross monthly rental revenue of the properties managed. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Property:  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Costs related to the development, redevelopment, construction and improvement of properties are capitalized. Interest incurred on development, redevelopment and construction
projects is capitalized until construction is substantially complete. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Maintenance
and repairs expenses are charged to operations as incurred. Costs for major replacements and betterments, which includes HVAC equipment, roofs, parking lots, etc., are capitalized and
depreciated over their estimated useful lives. Gains and losses are recognized upon disposal or retirement of the related assets and are reflected in&nbsp;earnings. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="RIGHT"><FONT SIZE=2><I>The Macerich Company&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>73</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=2,SEQ=75,EFW="2175451",CP="THE MACERICH COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=37037,FOLIO='73',FILE='DISK132:[07BHL4.07BHL1004]FG1004A.;19',USER='DCONRAD',CD='24-FEB-2007;02:37' -->
<A NAME="page_fg1004_1_74"> </A>
<BR>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Property
is recorded at cost and is depreciated using a straight-line method over the estimated useful lives of the assets as&nbsp;follows: </FONT></P>

<!-- User-specified TAGGED TABLE -->
<TABLE WIDTH="100%" BORDER=0 CELLSPACING=0 CELLPADDING=0>
<TR VALIGN="TOP">

</TR>

<TD WIDTH="49%"><FONT SIZE=2>Buildings and improvements</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="49%" ALIGN="RIGHT"><FONT SIZE=2>5-40&nbsp;years</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR BGCOLOR="White" VALIGN="TOP">
<TD WIDTH="49%"><FONT SIZE=2>Tenant improvements</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="49%" ALIGN="RIGHT"><FONT SIZE=2>5-7&nbsp;years</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR BGCOLOR="#CCEEFF" VALIGN="TOP">
<TD WIDTH="49%"><FONT SIZE=2>Equipment and furnishings</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="49%" ALIGN="RIGHT"><FONT SIZE=2>5-7&nbsp;years</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="TOP">
<TD COLSPAN=3><HR NOSHADE></TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<!-- end of user-specified TAGGED TABLE -->


<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Acquisitions:  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>The Company accounts for all acquisitions in accordance with Statement of Financial Accounting Standards ("SFAS") No.&nbsp;141, "Business Combinations." The Company will
first determine the value of the land and
buildings utilizing an "as if vacant" methodology. The Company will then assign a fair value to any debt assumed at acquisition. The balance of the purchase price will be allocated to tenant
improvements and identifiable intangible assets or liabilities. Tenant improvements represent the tangible assets associated with the existing leases valued on a fair market value basis at the
acquisition date prorated over the remaining lease terms. The tenant improvements are classified as an asset under real estate investments and are depreciated over the remaining lease terms.
Identifiable intangible assets and liabilities relate to the value of in-place operating leases which come in three forms: (i)&nbsp;leasing commissions and legal costs, which represent
the value associated with "cost avoidance" of acquiring in-place leases, such as lease commissions paid under terms generally experienced in the Company's markets; (ii)&nbsp;value of
in-place leases, which represents the estimated loss of revenue and of costs incurred for the period required to lease the "assumed vacant" property to the occupancy level when purchased;
and (iii)&nbsp;above or below market value of in-place leases, which represents the difference between the contractual rents and market rents at the time of the acquisition, discounted
for tenant credit risks. Leasing commissions and legal costs are recorded in deferred charges and other assets and are amortized over the remaining lease terms. The value of in-place
leases are recorded in deferred charges and other assets and amortized over the remaining lease terms plus an estimate of renewal of the acquired leases. Above or below market leases are classified
in deferred charges and other assets or in other accrued liabilities, depending on whether the contractual terms are above or below market, and the asset or liability is amortized to rental revenue
over the remaining terms of the&nbsp;leases. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>When
the Company acquires real estate properties, the Company allocates the purchase price to the components of these acquisitions using relative fair values computed using its estimates and
assumptions. These estimates and assumptions impact the amount of costs allocated between various components as well as the amount of costs assigned to individual properties in multiple property
acquisitions. These allocations also impact depreciation expense and gains or losses recorded on future sales of&nbsp;properties. Generally, the Company engages a valuation firm to assist with
these allocations. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>74</FONT> <FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Macerich Company</I></FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=3,SEQ=76,EFW="2175451",CP="THE MACERICH COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=404491,FOLIO='74',FILE='DISK132:[07BHL4.07BHL1004]FG1004A.;19',USER='DCONRAD',CD='24-FEB-2007;02:37' -->
<A NAME="page_fg1004_1_75"> </A>
<BR>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Marketable Securities:  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>The Company accounts for its investments in marketable securities as held-to-maturity debt securities under the provisions of
SFAS&nbsp;No.&nbsp;115, "Accounting for&nbsp;Certain Investments in Debt and Equity Securities," as the Company has the intent and the ability to hold these securities until maturity.
Accordingly, investments in marketable securities are carried at their amortized cost. The discount on marketable securities is amortized into interest income on a straight-line basis
over the term of the notes, which approximates the effective interest method. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Deferred Charges:  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Costs relating to obtaining tenant leases are deferred and amortized over the initial term of the agreement using the straight-line method. Costs relating to
financing of shopping center properties are deferred and amortized over the life of the related loan using the straight-line method, which approximates the effective interest method.
In-place lease values are amortized over the remaining lease term plus an estimate of renewal. Leasing commissions and legal costs are amortized on a straight-line basis over
the individual lease&nbsp;years. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>The
range of the terms of the agreements is as follows: </FONT></P>

<!-- User-specified TAGGED TABLE -->
<TABLE WIDTH="100%" BORDER=0 CELLSPACING=0 CELLPADDING=0>

</TR>

<TD WIDTH="3%"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="49%" ALIGN="RIGHT"><FONT SIZE=2>1-15&nbsp;years</FONT></TD>
</TR>

<TD WIDTH="49%"><FONT SIZE=2>Deferred financing costs</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="49%" ALIGN="RIGHT"><FONT SIZE=2>1-15&nbsp;years</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR BGCOLOR="#CCEEFF" VALIGN="TOP">
<TD WIDTH="49%"><FONT SIZE=2>In-place lease values</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="49%" ALIGN="RIGHT"><FONT SIZE=2>Remaining lease term plus an estimate for renewal</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR BGCOLOR="White" VALIGN="TOP">

</TR>

<TD COLSPAN=3><HR NOSHADE></TD>

</TABLE>
<!-- end of user-specified TAGGED TABLE -->


<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Accounting for the Impairment or Disposal of Long-Lived Assets:  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>The Company assesses whether there has been impairment in the value of its long-lived assets by considering expected future operating income, trends and prospects,
as well as the effects of demand, competition and other economic factors. Such factors include the tenants' ability to perform their duties and pay rent under the terms of the leases. The
determination of recoverability is made based upon the estimated undiscounted future net cash flows, excluding interest expense. The amount of impairment loss, if any, is determined by comparing the
fair value, as determined by an undiscounted cash flows analysis, with the carrying value of the related assets. Long-lived assets classified as held for sale are measured at the lower of
the carrying amount or fair value less cost to sell. Management does not believe impairment has occurred in its net property carrying values at December&nbsp;31, 2006 or&nbsp;2005. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Fair Value of Financial Instruments  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>The Company calculates the fair value of financial instruments and includes this additional information in the notes to consolidated financial statements when the fair value is
different than the carrying value of those financial instruments. When the fair value reasonably approximates the carrying value, no additional disclosure is made. The estimated fair value amounts
have been determined by the Company using available market </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="RIGHT"><FONT SIZE=2><I>The Macerich Company&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>75</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=4,SEQ=77,EFW="2175451",CP="THE MACERICH COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=920615,FOLIO='75',FILE='DISK132:[07BHL4.07BHL1004]FG1004A.;19',USER='DCONRAD',CD='24-FEB-2007;02:37' -->
<A NAME="page_fg1004_1_76"> </A>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>information
and appropriate valuation methodologies. However, considerable judgment is required in interpreting market data to develop the estimates of fair value. Accordingly, the estimates
presented herein are not necessarily indicative of the amounts that the Company could realize in a current market exchange. The use of different market assumptions and/or estimation methodologies may
have a material effect on the estimated fair value&nbsp;amounts. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Concentration of Risk:  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>The Company maintains its cash accounts in a number of commercial banks. Accounts at these banks are guaranteed by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation ("FDIC") up to
$100. At various times during the year, the Company had deposits in excess of the FDIC insurance limit. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>No
Center or tenant generated more than 10% of total revenues during 2006, 2005 or&nbsp;2004. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>The
Limited represented 3.5%, 4.1% and 3.6% of total minimum rents in place as of December&nbsp;31, 2006, 2005 and 2004, respectively, and no other retailer represented more than 2.9%, 3.6% and
3.2% of total minimum rents as of December&nbsp;31, 2006, 2005 and 2004, respectively. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Management Estimates:  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>The preparation of financial statements in conformity with GAAP requires management to make estimates and assumptions that affect the reported amounts of assets and liabilities
and disclosure of contingent assets and liabilities at the date of the financial statements and the reported amounts of revenues and expenses during the reporting period. Actual results could differ
from those estimates. In the year ending December&nbsp;31, 2004, the Company changed its estimate for common area expense recoveries applicable to prior periods. This change in estimate resulted in
a $4,129 charge for the year ending December&nbsp;31,&nbsp;2004. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Recent Accounting Pronouncements:  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>In December&nbsp;2004, the Financial Accounting Standards Board ("FASB") issued SFAS&nbsp;No.&nbsp;123 (revised), "Share-Based Payment." SFAS&nbsp;No.&nbsp;123(R)
requires that all share-based payments to employees, including grants of employee stock options, be recognized in the income statement based on their fair values. The Company adopted this statement
as of January&nbsp;1, 2006. See Note&nbsp;16 &#151;Share-Based Plans, for&nbsp;the impact of the adoption of SFAS&nbsp;No.&nbsp;123(R) on the results of&nbsp;operations. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>In
March&nbsp;2005, FASB issued Interpretation No.&nbsp;47 ("FIN&nbsp;47"), "Accounting for Conditional Asset Retirement Obligations &#151;an interpretation of
SFAS&nbsp;No.&nbsp;143." FIN&nbsp;47, requires that a liability be recognized for the fair value of a conditional asset retirement obligation if the fair value can be reasonably estimated. As a
result of the Company's adoption of FIN&nbsp;47, the Company recorded an additional liability of $615 in 2005. As of December&nbsp;31, 2006 and 2005, the Company's liability for retirement
obligations was $414 and $1,163, respectively. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>76</FONT> <FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Macerich Company</I></FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=5,SEQ=78,EFW="2175451",CP="THE MACERICH COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=792529,FOLIO='76',FILE='DISK132:[07BHL4.07BHL1004]FG1004A.;19',USER='DCONRAD',CD='24-FEB-2007;02:37' -->
<A NAME="page_fg1004_1_77"> </A>
<BR>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>In
February&nbsp;2006, the FASB issued SFAS&nbsp;No.&nbsp;155, "Accounting for&nbsp;Certain Hybrid Financial Instruments &#151;An Amendment of FASB Statements No.&nbsp;133
and&nbsp;140." This statement amended SFAS&nbsp;No.&nbsp;133, "Accounting for&nbsp;Derivative Instruments and Hedging Activities," and No.&nbsp;140, "Accounting for&nbsp;Transfers and
Servicing of Financial Assets and Extinguishments of Liabilities." SFAS&nbsp;No.&nbsp;155 permits fair value remeasurement for any hybrid financial instrument that contains an embedded derivative
that otherwise would require bifurcation. This statement also established a requirement to evaluate interests in securitized financial assets to identify interests that are freestanding derivatives
or that are hybrid financial instruments that contain an embedded derivative requiring bifurcation. The Company is required to adopt SFAS&nbsp;No.&nbsp;155 for&nbsp;fiscal year 2007 and
does not expect its adoption to have a material effect on the Company's results of operations or financial condition. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>In
June&nbsp;2006, the FASB issued Interpretation No.&nbsp;48, "Accounting for&nbsp;Uncertainty in Income Taxes &#151;an interpretation of FASB Statement No.&nbsp;109"
("FIN&nbsp;48"). This interpretation clarifies the accounting for uncertainty in income taxes recognized in an enterprise's financial statements in accordance with SFAS&nbsp;No.&nbsp;109,
"Accounting for&nbsp;Income Taxes." This interpretation prescribes a recognition threshold and measurement attribute for the financial statement recognition and measurement of a tax position taken
or expected to be taken in a tax return. This interpretation also provides guidance on derecognition of previously recognized income tax benefits, classification, interest and penalties, accounting
in interim periods, disclosure, and transition. FIN&nbsp;48 is effective for fiscal years beginning after December&nbsp;15, 2006. The Company has concluded that the adoption of FIN&nbsp;48 will
not have a material impact on its consolidated financial statements. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>In
September&nbsp;2006, the FASB issued SFAS&nbsp;No.&nbsp;157, "Fair Value Measurements." SFAS&nbsp;No.&nbsp;157 defines fair value, establishes a framework for measuring fair value, and
expands disclosures about fair value measurements. The Company is required to adopt SFAS&nbsp;No.&nbsp;157 for&nbsp;fiscal year 2008 and does not expect its adoption to have a material effect
on the Company's results of operations or financial condition. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>In
September&nbsp;2006, the Securities and Exchange Commission issued Staff Accounting Bulletin ("SAB") No.&nbsp;108. SAB&nbsp;No.&nbsp;108 establishes a framework for quantifying materiality
of financial statement misstatements. SAB&nbsp;No.&nbsp;108 is effective for fiscal years ending after November&nbsp;16, 2006. The adoption of SAB&nbsp;No.&nbsp;108 did not have a material
impact on the Company's consolidated results of operations or financial condition. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>3.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Earnings per Share ("EPS"):  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>The computation of basic earnings per share is based on net income and the weighted average number of common shares outstanding for the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2006,
2005 and 2004. The computation of diluted earnings per share includes the effect of dilutive securities calculated using the treasury stock method. The OP Units not held by the Company have been
included in the diluted EPS calculation since they may be redeemable on a one-for-one basis, at the Company's option. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="RIGHT"><FONT SIZE=2><I>The Macerich Company&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>77</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='page-break-before:always'></p>

<DL compact>
<DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2><I>(1)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2><I> The Operating Partnership's ownership interest in this table reflects its legal ownership interest but may not reflect its economic interest since each joint venture has various
agreements regarding cash flow, profits and losses, allocations, capital requirements and other matters.  </I></FONT></DD></DL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>The Company accounts for its investments in joint ventures using the equity method of accounting unless the Company has a controlling interest in the joint venture or is the
primary beneficiary in a variable interest entity. Although the Company has a greater than 50% interest in Pacific Premier Retail Trust, Camelback Colonnade SPE&nbsp;LLC and Corte Madera
Village,&nbsp;LLC, the Company shares management control with the partners in these joint ventures and accounts for these joint ventures using the equity method of&nbsp;accounting. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>The
Company has acquired the following investments in unconsolidated joint ventures during the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2006, 2005 and&nbsp;2004: </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>On
January&nbsp;30, 2004, the Company, in a 50/50 joint venture with a private investment company, acquired Inland Center, a 1&nbsp;million square&nbsp;foot super-regional mall in San
Bernardino, California. The total purchase price was $63,300 and concurrently with the acquisition, the joint venture placed a $54,000 fixed rate loan on the property. The balance of the Company's
pro&nbsp;rata share of the purchase price was funded by cash and borrowings under the Company's line of credit. The results of Inland Center are included below for the period subsequent to its date
of&nbsp;acquisition. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>On
May&nbsp;11, 2004, the Company acquired an ownership interest in NorthPark Center, a 2.0&nbsp;million square&nbsp;foot regional mall in Dallas, Texas. The Company's initial investment in the
property was $30,005 which was funded by borrowings under the Company's line of credit. In addition, the Company assumed a pro&nbsp;rata share of debt of $86,599 and funded an additional $45,000
post-closing. The results of NorthPark Center are included below for the period subsequent to its date of&nbsp;acquisition. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>On
January&nbsp;11, 2005, the Company became a 15% owner in a joint venture that acquired Metrocenter Mall, a 1.3&nbsp;million square&nbsp;foot super-regional mall in Phoenix, Arizona. The
total purchase price was $160,000 and concurrently with the acquisition, the joint venture placed a $112,000 floating rate loan on the property. The </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>80</FONT> <FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Macerich Company</I></FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=9,SEQ=82,EFW="2175451",CP="THE MACERICH COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=119467,FOLIO='80',FILE='DISK132:[07BHL4.07BHL1004]FG1004B.;28',USER='DCONRAD',CD='24-FEB-2007;02:37' -->
<A NAME="page_fg1004_1_81"> </A>
<BR>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Company's
share of the purchase price, net of the debt, was $7,200 which was funded by cash and borrowings under the Company's line of credit. The results of Metrocenter Mall are included below for
the period subsequent to its date of&nbsp;acquisition. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>On
January&nbsp;21, 2005, the Company formed a 50/50 joint venture with a private investment company. The joint venture acquired a 49% interest in Kierland Commons, a
438,721&nbsp;square&nbsp;foot mixed use center in Phoenix, Arizona. The joint venture's purchase price for the interest in the center was $49,000. The Company assumed its share of the underlying
property debt and funded the remainder of its share of the purchase price by cash and borrowings under the Company's line of credit. The results of Kierland Commons are included below for the period
subsequent to its date of&nbsp;acquisition. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>On
April&nbsp;8, 2005, the Company in a 50/50 joint venture with an affiliate of Walton Street Capital,&nbsp;LLC, acquired Ridgmar Mall, a 1.3&nbsp;million square&nbsp;foot super-regional
mall in Fort Worth, Texas. The total purchase price was $71,075 and concurrently with the transaction, the joint venture placed a $57,400 fixed rate loan of 6.0725% on
the property. The balance of the Company's pro&nbsp;rata share, $6,838, of the purchase price was funded by borrowings under the Company's line of credit. The results of Ridgmar Mall are included
below for the period subsequent to its date of&nbsp;acquisition. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>On
April&nbsp;25, 2005, as part of the Wilmorite acquisition (See&nbsp;Note&nbsp;12 &#151;Acquisitions), the Company became a 50% joint venture partner in Tyson's Corner Center, a
2.2&nbsp;million square&nbsp;foot super-regional mall in McLean, Virginia. The results of Tyson's Corner Center are included below for the period subsequent to its date of&nbsp;acquisition. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>Combined
and condensed balance sheets and statements of operations are presented below for all unconsolidated joint&nbsp;ventures. </FONT></P>

<DL compact>
<DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2><I>(2)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2><I> Certain joint ventures have debt that could become recourse debt to the Company should the joint venture be unable to discharge the obligations of the related debt. As of
December&nbsp;31, 2006 and 2005, a total of $8,570 and $21,630 could become recourse debt to the Company, respectively.  </I></FONT></DD></DL>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>82</FONT> <FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Macerich Company</I></FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=11,SEQ=84,EFW="2175451",CP="THE MACERICH COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=248323,FOLIO='82',FILE='DISK132:[07BHL4.07BHL1004]FG1004B.;28',USER='DCONRAD',CD='24-FEB-2007;02:37' -->
<A NAME="page_fg1004_1_83"> </A>
<DL compact>
<DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2><I>(3)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2><I> The Company's investment in joint ventures is $451,208 and $456,818 more than the underlying equity as reflected in the joint ventures financial statements as of December&nbsp;31,
2006 and 2005, respectively. This represents the difference between the cost of an investment and the book value of the underlying equity of the joint venture. The Company is amortizing this
difference into income on a straight-line basis, consistent with the depreciable lives on property (See&nbsp;"Note&nbsp;2 &#151;Summary of Significant Accounting Policies").
The amortization of this difference was $14,847, $14,326 and $13,758 for the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2006, 2005 and 2004, respectively.</I></FONT></DD></DL>

<P ALIGN="RIGHT"><FONT SIZE=2><I>The Macerich Company&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>83</FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Significant accounting policies used by the unconsolidated joint ventures are similar to those used by the Company. Included in mortgage notes payable are amounts due to
affiliates of Northwestern Mutual Life ("NML") of $132,170 and $137,954 as of December&nbsp;31, 2006 and 2005 respectively. NML is considered a related party because they are a joint
venture partner with the Company in Macerich Northwestern Associates. Interest expense incurred on these borrowings amounted to $9,082, $9,422 and $9,814 for the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2006,
2005 and 2004, respectively. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>5.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Derivative Instruments and Hedging Activities  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>The Company recognizes all derivatives in the consolidated financial statements and measures the derivatives at fair value. The Company uses derivative financial instruments in
the normal course of business to manage or reduce its exposure to adverse fluctuations in interest rates. The Company designs its hedges to be effective in reducing the risk exposure that they are
designated to hedge. Any instrument that meets the cash flow hedging criteria in SFAS&nbsp;133, "Accounting for Derivative Instruments and Hedging Activities," is formally designated as a </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="RIGHT"><FONT SIZE=2><I>The Macerich Company&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>85</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=1,SEQ=87,EFW="2175451",CP="THE MACERICH COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=431313,FOLIO='85',FILE='DISK132:[07BHL4.07BHL1004]FI1004A.;53',USER='CMATTI',CD='26-FEB-2007;19:41' -->
<A NAME="page_fi1004_1_86"> </A>
<BR>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>cash
flow hedge at the inception of the derivative contract. On an ongoing quarterly basis, the Company adjusts its balance sheet to reflect the current fair value of its derivatives. To the extent
they are effective, changes in fair value of derivatives are recorded in comprehensive income. Ineffective portions, if any, are included in net income. No ineffectiveness was recorded in net income
during the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2006, 2005 or 2004. If any derivative instrument used for risk management does not meet the hedging criteria, it is marked-to-market
each period in the consolidated statements of operations. As of December&nbsp;31, 2006, five of the Company's derivative instruments were not designated as cash flow&nbsp;hedges. Changes in the
market value of these derivative instruments will be recorded in the consolidated statements of operations. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>As
of December&nbsp;31, 2006 and 2005, the Company had $1,252 and $2,762, respectively, reflected in other comprehensive income related to treasury rate locks settled in prior years. The Company
reclassified $1,510, $1,351 and $1,351 for the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2006, 2005 and 2004, respectively, related to treasury rate lock transactions settled in prior years from accumulated
other comprehensive income to earnings. It is anticipated that the remaining $1,252 will be reclassified during the following&nbsp;year. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>Interest
rate swap and cap agreements are purchased by the Company from third parties to manage the risk of interest rate changes on some of the Company's floating rate debt. Payments received as a
result of these agreements are recorded as a reduction of interest expense. The fair value of the instrument is included in deferred charges and other assets if the fair value is an asset or in other
accrued liabilities if the fair value is a deficit. The Company recorded other comprehensive income (loss) of $743, ($2,356) and $2,076 related to the marking-to-market of
interest rate swap/cap agreements for the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2006, 2005 and 2004, respectively. The amount expected to be reclassified to interest expense in the next 12 months will be
immaterial. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>90</FONT> <FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Macerich Company</I></FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=6,SEQ=92,EFW="2175451",CP="THE MACERICH COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=841958,FOLIO='90',FILE='DISK132:[07BHL4.07BHL1004]FI1004A.;53',USER='CMATTI',CD='26-FEB-2007;19:41' -->
<A NAME="page_fi1004_1_91"> </A>
<DL compact>
<DT style='margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(a)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> The mortgage notes payable balances include the unamortized debt premiums (discount). Debt premiums (discount) represent the excess (deficiency) of the fair value of debt over
(under) the principal value of debt assumed in various acquisitions and are amortized into interest expense over the remaining term of the related debt in a manner that approximates the effective
interest method. The interest rate represents the effective interest rate, including the debt premium (discount).</I></FONT></DD></DL>
<UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=1><I> Debt premiums (discounts) as of December&nbsp;31, 2006 and 2005 consist of the&nbsp;following:</I></FONT></P>
</UL>
