<DL compact>
<DT style='margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(b)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> This represents the monthly payment of principal and interest.
<BR><BR> </I></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(c)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> On August&nbsp;16, 2006, the Company placed a construction note payable on the property for up to $110,000, which bears interest at LIBOR plus a spread of 1.20% to
1.40% depending
on certain conditions. The loan matures in August 2009, with two one-year extension options. At December&nbsp;31, 2006, the total interest rate was&nbsp;6.75%.
<BR><BR> </I></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(d)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> In addition to monthly principal and interest payments, contingent interest, as defined in the loan agreement, may be due to the extent that 35% of the amount by
which the property's
gross receipts exceeds a base amount. Contingent interest expense recognized by the Company was $576, $696 and $658 for the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2006, 2005 and 2004, respectively.
<BR><BR> </I></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(e)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> These loans were paid off in full on December&nbsp;29, 2006 concurrent with the sale of the property (See&nbsp;Note&nbsp;13&#151;Discontinued Operations).
<BR><BR> </I></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(f)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> On July&nbsp;20, 2006, the Company placed a $61,200 loan that bears interest at 6.26% and was set to mature in August&nbsp;2016. The loan was assumed by a third
party concurrent
with sale of the property on December&nbsp;29, 2006 (See&nbsp;Note&nbsp;13&#151;Discontinued Operations).
<BR><BR> </I></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(g)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> On December&nbsp;7, 2006, the Company placed an interest only $100,000 loan that bears interest at 5.44% and matures in January&nbsp;2013. The loan provides for
additional
borrowings of up to $72,500 during the one-year period ending December&nbsp;7, 2007, subject to certain conditions.
<BR><BR> </I></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(h)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> The floating rate loan bears interest at LIBOR plus 0.65%. The Company has stepped interest rate cap agreements over the term of the loan that effectively prevent
LIBOR from
exceeding 7.95%. At December&nbsp;31, 2006 and 2005, the total interest rate was 6.0% and 5.02%, respectively.  </I></FONT></DD></DL>
<P ALIGN="RIGHT"><FONT SIZE=2><I>The Macerich Company&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>91</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=7,SEQ=93,EFW="2175451",CP="THE MACERICH COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=830903,FOLIO='91',FILE='DISK132:[07BHL4.07BHL1004]FI1004A.;53',USER='CMATTI',CD='26-FEB-2007;19:41' -->
<A NAME="page_fi1004_1_92"> </A>
<DL compact>
<DT style='margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(i)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> The loan is no longer collateralized by the Greeley Mall. In conjunction with the defeasance described in Note&nbsp;10 &#151;Bank and Other Notes Payable, this loan is now
classified as a note&nbsp;payable.
<BR><BR> </I></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(j)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> The floating rate loan bears interest at LIBOR plus 0.88% that matures on August&nbsp;9, 2007 with two one-year extensions through August&nbsp;9, 2009. The Company
has an interest rate cap agreement over the loan term which effectively prevents LIBOR from exceeding 7.12%. At December&nbsp;31, 2006 and 2005, the total interest rate was 6.23% and 5.25%,
respectively.
<BR><BR> </I></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(k)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> This represents a construction loan that bore interest at LIBOR plus 2.0%. On January&nbsp;6, 2006, the Company modified the loan to reduce the interest rate to
LIBOR plus 1.75%
with the opportunity for further reduction upon satisfaction of certain conditions to LIBOR plus 1.50%. The maturity was extended to August&nbsp;1, 2008 with two extension options of eighteen and
twelve months, respectively. At December&nbsp;31, 2006 and 2005, the total interest rate was 7.08% and 6.39%, respectively.
<BR><BR> </I></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(l)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> The loan bore interest at LIBOR plus 2.0% for six months and then converted at January&nbsp;1, 2005 to a fixed rate loan at 4.94%. The effective interest rate over
the entire term
is&nbsp;4.84%.
<BR><BR> </I></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(m)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> Concurrent with the acquisition of the property, the Company placed a $108,000 loan bearing interest at LIBOR plus 1.15% and maturing July&nbsp;1, 2004 with three
consecutive
one-year options. $92,000 of the loan was at LIBOR plus 0.7% and $16,000 was at LIBOR plus 3.75%. The Company extended the loan maturity to July&nbsp;2007. In May&nbsp;2006, the
Company paid off $16,000 of the loan. On February&nbsp;2, 2007, the Company paid off the remaining $92,000 loan balance. The Company had an interest rate cap agreement over the loan term which
effectively prevented LIBOR from exceeding 7.10%. At December&nbsp;31, 2006 and 2005, the total interest rate was 6.05% and 5.25%, respectively.
<BR><BR> </I></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(n)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> On February&nbsp;15, 2006, the Company paid off the existing $32,250 floating rate loan that bore interest at LIBOR plus 1.65% and replaced it with a $50,000
floating rate loan
that bears interest at LIBOR plus 0.85% and matures in February&nbsp;2010. There is an interest rate cap agreement on the new loan which effectively prevents LIBOR from exceeding 6.65%. At
December&nbsp;31, 2006 and 2005, the total interest rate was 6.23% and 4.90%, respectively.
<BR><BR> </I></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(o)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> This loan was paid off in full on January&nbsp;2, 2007.
<BR><BR> </I></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(p)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> On November&nbsp;14, 2006, the Company paid off the existing $35,280 floating rate loan and replaced it with a $60,000 fixed rate loan that bears interest of 5.78%
and matures in
December&nbsp;2011. At December&nbsp;31, 2006 and 2005, the total interest rate was 5.78% and 6.03%, respectively.
<BR><BR> </I></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(q)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> This loan was paid off in full on January&nbsp;3, 2006.
<BR><BR> </I></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(r)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> This loan was paid off in full on September&nbsp;1, 2006.
<BR><BR> </I></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(s)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> This floating rate loan bore interest at LIBOR plus 1.375% and was to mature on February&nbsp;20, 2006. On April&nbsp;19, 2006, the Company refinanced the loan on
the property.
The existing loan was replaced with a $115,000 loan bearing interest at 5.79% and maturing on May&nbsp;1,&nbsp;2016.
<BR><BR> </I></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(t)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> The loan was paid off in June&nbsp;2006 concurrent with the sale of the property (See&nbsp;Note&nbsp;13 &#151;Discontinued Operations).
<BR><BR> </I></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(u)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> On June&nbsp;7, 2006, the Company placed a construction note payable on the property for up to $115,000, which bears interest at LIBOR plus a spread of 1.1% to 1.25%
depending on
certain conditions. The loan matures in June&nbsp;2007, with two one-year extension options. At December&nbsp;31, 2006, the total interest rate was&nbsp;6.67%.
<BR><BR> </I></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(v)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> Concurrent with the acquisition of this property, the Company placed a $100,000 loan that bears interest at 5.58% and matures on February&nbsp;16, 2016. On
January&nbsp;23, 2007,
the Company exercised an earn-out provision under the loan agreement and borrowed an additional $20,000 at a fixed rate of 5.64%.  </I></FONT></DD></DL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>92</FONT> <FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Macerich Company</I></FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='page-break-before:always'></p>

<!-- ZEQ.=8,SEQ=94,EFW="2175451",CP="THE MACERICH COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=416206,FOLIO='92',FILE='DISK132:[07BHL4.07BHL1004]FI1004A.;53',USER='CMATTI',CD='26-FEB-2007;19:41' -->
<A NAME="page_fi1004_1_93"> </A>
<DL compact>
<DT style='margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(w)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> The loan was paid off in on January&nbsp;3, 2006.
<BR><BR> </I></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(x)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> This loan was paid off in full on August&nbsp;1, 2006.  </I></FONT></DD></DL>

<P><FONT SIZE=1><I> Most of the mortgage loan agreements contain a prepayment penalty provision for the early extinguishment of the&nbsp;debt.  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=1><I> Total interest expense capitalized during 2006, 2005 and 2004 was $14,927, $9,994 and $12,132, respectively.  </I></FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=1><I> Related party mortgage notes payable are amounts due to affiliates of NML. See Note&nbsp;11 &#151;Related Party Transactions, for interest expense associated with loans from&nbsp;NML.  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=1><I> The fair value of mortgage notes payable is estimated to be approximately $3,854,913 and $3,341,000, at December&nbsp;31, 2006 and 2005, respectively, based on current interest rates for comparable
loans.  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=1><I> The above debt matures as follows:  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>10.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Bank and Other Notes Payable:  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>The Company had a $1,000,000 revolving line of credit that was set to mature on July&nbsp;30, 2007 plus a one-year extension. On July&nbsp;20, 2006, the Company
amended and expanded the revolving line of credit to $1,500,000 and extended the maturity to April&nbsp;25, 2010 with a one-year extension option. The interest rate, after amendment,
fluctuated from LIBOR plus 1.0% to LIBOR plus 1.35% depending on the Company's overall leverage. In September&nbsp;2006, the Company entered into an interest rate swap agreement that effectively
fixed the interest rate on $400,000 of the outstanding balance of the line of credit at 6.23% until April&nbsp;25, 2011. As of December&nbsp;31, 2006 and 2005, borrowings outstanding were
$934,500 and $863,000 at an average interest rate, net of the $400,000 swapped portion, of 6.60% and 5.93%, respectively. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="RIGHT"><FONT SIZE=2><I>The Macerich Company&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>93</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=9,SEQ=95,EFW="2175451",CP="THE MACERICH COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=622375,FOLIO='93',FILE='DISK132:[07BHL4.07BHL1004]FI1004B.;24',USER='CMATTI',CD='26-FEB-2007;19:41' -->
<A NAME="page_fi1004_1_94"> </A>
<BR>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>On
May&nbsp;13, 2003, the Company issued $250,000 in unsecured notes maturing in May&nbsp;2007 with a one-year extension option bearing interest at LIBOR plus 2.50%. The proceeds were
used to pay down the Company's line of credit. At December&nbsp;31, 2006 and 2005, $250,000 was outstanding at an interest rate of 6.94% and 6.0%, respectively. The Company had an interest rate
swap agreement from November&nbsp;2003 to October&nbsp;13, 2005, which effectively fixed the LIBOR rate at 4.45%. On April&nbsp;25, 2005, the Company modified the notes and reduced the interest
rate from LIBOR plus 2.5% to LIBOR plus&nbsp;1.5%. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>On
April&nbsp;25, 2005, concurrent with the Wilmorite acquisition (See&nbsp;Note&nbsp;12 &#151;Acquisitions), the Company obtained a five-year, $450,000 term loan bearing
interest at LIBOR plus 1.50% and a $650,000 acquisition loan which had a term of up to two years and bore interest initially at LIBOR plus 1.60%. In November&nbsp;2005, the Company entered into an
interest rate swap agreement that effectively fixed the interest rate of the $450,000 term loan at 6.30% from December&nbsp;1, 2005 to April&nbsp;25, 2010. At December&nbsp;31, 2005, the entire
term loan and $619,000 of the acquisition loan were outstanding with interest rates of 6.30% and 6.04%, respectively. On January&nbsp;19, 2006, concurrent with a stock offering
(See&nbsp;Note&nbsp;20 &#151;Stock Offering), the acquisition loan was paid off in full, resulting in a loss on early extinguishment of debt of $1,782. As of December&nbsp;31, 2006, the
entire term loan was outstanding with an interest rate of&nbsp;6.30%. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>On
July&nbsp;27, 2006, concurrent with the sale of Greeley Mall (See&nbsp;Note&nbsp;13 &#151;Discontinued Operations), the Company provided marketable securities to replace Greeley Mall
as collateral for the mortgage note payable on the property. As a result of this transaction, the debt has been reclassified to bank and other notes payable.
This note bears interest at 6.18% and matures in September&nbsp;2013. As of December&nbsp;31, 2006, the note had a balance outstanding of&nbsp;$28,281. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>As
of December&nbsp;31, 2006 and 2005, the Company was in compliance with all applicable loan&nbsp;covenants. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>11.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Related-Party Transactions:  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Certain unconsolidated joint ventures have engaged the Management Companies to manage the operations of the Centers. Under these arrangements, the Management Companies are
reimbursed for compensation paid to on-site employees, leasing agents and project managers at the Centers, as well as insurance costs and other </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Certain mortgage notes on the properties are held by NML (See&nbsp;Note&nbsp;9 &#151;Mortgage Notes Payable). Interest expense in connection with these notes was
$10,860, $9,638 and $5,800 for the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2006, 2005 and 2004, respectively. Included in accounts payable and accrued expenses is interest payable to these partners of $793
and $782 at December&nbsp;31, 2006 and 2005, respectively. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>As
of December&nbsp;31, 2006 and 2005, the Company had loans to unconsolidated joint ventures of $708 and $1,415, respectively. Interest income associated with these notes was $734, $452 and $426
for the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2006, 2005 and 2004, respectively. These loans represent initial funds advanced to development stage projects prior to construction loan funding.
Correspondingly, loan payables in the same amount have been accrued as an obligation by the various joint&nbsp;ventures. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Due
from affiliates of $4,282 and $4,258 at December&nbsp;31, 2006 and 2005, respectively, represents unreimbursed costs and fees due from unconsolidated joint ventures under management agreements. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Certain
Company officers and affiliates have guaranteed mortgages of $21,750 at one of the Company's joint venture properties. </FONT></P>

<!-- ZEQ.=11,SEQ=97,EFW="2175451",CP="THE MACERICH COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=470989,FOLIO='95',FILE='DISK132:[07BHL4.07BHL1004]FI1004B.;24',USER='CMATTI',CD='26-FEB-2007;19:41' -->
<A NAME="page_fi1004_1_96"> </A>
<BR>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>12.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Acquisitions:  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>The Company has completed the following acquisitions during the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2006, 2005 and&nbsp;2004: </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Wilmorite:  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>On April&nbsp;25, 2005, the Company and the Operating Partnership acquired Wilmorite Properties,&nbsp;Inc., a Delaware corporation ("Wilmorite") and Wilmorite
Holdings,&nbsp;L.P., a Delaware limited partnership ("Wilmorite Holdings"). The results of Wilmorite and Wilmorite Holding's operations have been included in the Company's consolidated financial
statements since that date. Wilmorite's portfolio included interests in 11&nbsp;regional malls and two open-air community shopping centers with 13.4&nbsp;million square&nbsp;feet of
space located in Connecticut, New&nbsp;York, New&nbsp;Jersey, Kentucky and&nbsp;Virginia. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>The
total purchase price was approximately $2,333,333, plus adjustments for working capital, including the assumption of approximately $877,174 of existing debt with an average interest rate of 6.43%
and the issuance of $212,668 of participating convertible preferred units ("PCPUs"), $21,501 of non-participating convertible
preferred units and $5,815 of common units in Wilmorite Holdings. The balance of the consideration to the equity holders of Wilmorite and Wilmorite Holdings was paid in cash, which was provided
primarily by a five-year, $450,000 term loan bearing interest at LIBOR plus 1.50% and a $650,000 acquisition loan which had a term of up to two years and bore interest initially at LIBOR
plus 1.60%. In January&nbsp;2006, the acquisition loan was paid off in full (See&nbsp;Note&nbsp;10 &#151;Bank and&nbsp;Other Notes Payable). An affiliate of the Operating Partnership
is the general partner, and together with other affiliates, own approximately 83% of Wilmorite Holdings, with the remaining 17% held by those limited partners of Wilmorite Holdings who elected to
receive convertible preferred units or common units in Wilmorite Holdings rather than cash. The PCPUs can be redeemed, subject to certain conditions, for the portion of the Wilmorite portfolio that
consists of Eastview Mall, Eastview Commons, Greece Ridge Center, Marketplace Mall and Pittsford Plaza. That right is exercisable during a period of three months beginning on
August&nbsp;31,&nbsp;2007. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>On
an unaudited pro&nbsp;forma basis, reflecting the acquisition of Wilmorite as if it had occurred on January&nbsp;1, 2004, the Company would have reflected net income available to common
stockholders of $41,962 and $52,808, net income available to common stockholders on a diluted per share basis of $0.71 and $0.90 and total consolidated revenues of $832,152 and $750,205&nbsp;for
the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2005 and 2004, respectively. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>96</FONT> <FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Macerich Company</I></FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='page-break-before:always'></p>

<A NAME="page_fi1004_1_97"> </A>

<TD WIDTH="2%"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>

<TD WIDTH="14%" ALIGN="RIGHT"><FONT SIZE=2>$1,431,514</FONT></TD>

<!-- end of user-specified TAGGED TABLE -->


<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Valley River:  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>On February&nbsp;1, 2006, the Company acquired Valley River Center, an 835,694&nbsp;square&nbsp;foot super-regional mall in Eugene, Oregon. The total purchase price was
$187,500 and concurrent with the acquisition, the Company placed a $100,000 loan on the property. The balance of the purchase price was funded by cash and borrowings under the Company's line of
credit. The results of Valley River Center's operations have been included in the Company's consolidated financial statements since the acquisition&nbsp;date. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Federated:  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>On July&nbsp;26, 2006, the Company purchased 11&nbsp;department stores located in 10 of its Centers from Federated Department Stores,&nbsp;Inc. for approximately
$100,000. The purchase price consisted of a $93,000 cash payment and a future $7,000 obligation to be paid in connection with future development work by Federated. The Company's share of the purchase
price of $81,043 was funded in part from the proceeds of sales of properties and from borrowings under the line of credit. The balance of the purchase price was paid by the Company's joint venture
partners where four of the eleven stores were&nbsp;located. The purchase price allocation included in the Company's balance sheet as of December&nbsp;31, 2006 was based on information available
at that time. Subsequent adjustments to the allocation may be made based on additional information. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Deptford:  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>On December&nbsp;1, 2006, the Company acquired the Deptford Mall, a 1,039,840&nbsp;square&nbsp;foot super-regional mall in Deptford, New&nbsp;Jersey. The total purchase
price was $240,055. The purchase price was funded by cash and borrowings under the Company's line of credit. Subsequently, the Company placed a $100,000 loan on the property. The proceeds from the
loan were used to pay down the Company's line of credit. The results of Deptford Mall's operations have been included in the Company's consolidated financial statements since the
acquisition&nbsp;date. The purchase price allocation included in the Company's balance sheet as of December&nbsp;31, 2006 was based on information available at that time. Subsequent adjustments
to the allocation will be made based on additional information. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="RIGHT"><FONT SIZE=2><I>The Macerich Company&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>97</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=13,SEQ=99,EFW="2175451",CP="THE MACERICH COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=338067,FOLIO='97',FILE='DISK132:[07BHL4.07BHL1004]FI1004B.;24',USER='CMATTI',CD='26-FEB-2007;19:41' -->
<!-- THIS IS THE END OF A COMPOSITION COMPONENT -->

<P><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="page_fk1004_1_98"> </A> </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>13.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Discontinued Operations:  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>The following dispositions occurred during the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2006, 2005 and&nbsp;2004: </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>On
December&nbsp;16, 2004, the Company sold Westbar for $47,500 resulting in a gain on sale of asset of $6,781. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>On
January&nbsp;5, 2005, the Company sold Arizona Lifestyle Galleries for $4,300. The sale of this property resulted in a gain on sale of asset of $297. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>On
June&nbsp;9, 2006, the Company sold Scottsdale/101&nbsp;for $117,600 resulting in a gain on sale of asset of $62,633. The Company's share of the gain was $25,802. The Company's pro&nbsp;rata
share of the proceeds were used to pay down the Company's line of credit. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>On
July&nbsp;13, 2006, the Company sold Park Lane Mall for $20,000 resulting in a gain on sale of asset of $5,853. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>On
July&nbsp;27, 2006, the Company sold Holiday Village and Greeley Mall in a combined sale for $86,800, resulting in a gain on sale of asset of $28,711. Concurrent with the sale, the Company
defeased the mortgage note payable on Greeley Mall. As a result of the defeasance, the lender's secured interest in the property was replaced with a secured interest in marketable securities
(See&nbsp;Note&nbsp;7&#151;Marketable Securities). This transaction did not
meet the criteria for extinguishment of debt under SFAS No.&nbsp;140, "Accounting for Transfers and Servicing of Financial Assets and Extinguishment of Liabilities." </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>On
August&nbsp;11, 2006, the Company sold Great Falls Marketplace for $27,500 resulting in a gain on sale of asset of $11,826. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>The
proceeds from the sale of Park Lane, Holiday Village, Greeley Mall and Great Falls Marketplace were used in part to fund the Company's pro&nbsp;rata share of the purchase price of the Federated
stores acquisition (See&nbsp;Note&nbsp;12&#151;Acquisitions) and&nbsp;pay down the line of&nbsp;credit. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>On
December&nbsp;29, 2006, the Company sold Citadel Mall, Northwest Arkansas Mall and Crossroads Mall in a combined sale for $373,800, resulting in a gain of $132,671. The proceeds were used to pay
down the Company's line of credit and pay off the mortgage note payable on Paradise Valley Mall (See&nbsp;Note&nbsp;9&#151;Mortgage Notes Payable). </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>The
Company has classified the results of operations for the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2006, 2005 and 2004 for all of the above dispositions as discontinued operations. The carrying value of
the properties sold in 2006 at December&nbsp;31, 2005 and 2004 was $168,475 and $171,283, respectively. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>98</FONT> <FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Macerich Company</I></FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>

<P style='page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=2,SEQ=101,EFW="2175451",CP="THE MACERICH COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=1025122,FOLIO='99',FILE='DISK132:[07BHL4.07BHL1004]FK1004A.;67',USER='GKIBBE',CD='27-FEB-2007;10:09' -->
<A NAME="page_fk1004_1_100"> </A>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>14.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Future Rental Revenues:  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>15.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Commitments and Contingencies:  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>The Company has certain properties subject to non-cancelable operating ground leases. The leases expire at various times through 2097, subject in some cases to
options to extend the terms of the lease. Certain leases provide for contingent rent payments based on a percentage of base rental income, as defined. Ground rent expenses were $4,235, $3,860 and
$2,530 for the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2006, 2005 and 2004, respectively. No contingent rent was incurred for the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2006, 2005 and&nbsp;2004. </FONT></P>

future rental payments required under the leases are as follows: </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>As of December&nbsp;31, 2006 and 2005, the Company is contingently liable for $6,087 and $5,616, respectively, in letters of credit guaranteeing performance

<P><FONT SIZE=2>100</FONT> <FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Macerich Company</I></FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=3,SEQ=102,EFW="2175451",CP="THE MACERICH COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=1014003,FOLIO='100',FILE='DISK132:[07BHL4.07BHL1004]FK1004A.;67',USER='GKIBBE',CD='27-FEB-2007;10:09' -->
<A NAME="page_fk1004_1_101"> </A>
<BR>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>16.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Share-Based Plans:  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>The Company has established share-based compensation plans for the purpose of attracting and retaining executive officers, directors and key employees. In addition, the Company
has established an Employee Stock Purchase Plan ("ESPP") to allow employees to purchase the Company's common stock at a&nbsp;discount. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>On
January&nbsp;1, 2006, the Company adopted SFAS&nbsp;No.&nbsp;123(R), "Share-Based Payment," to&nbsp;account for its share-based compensation plans using the modified-prospective method.
Accordingly, prior period amounts have not been restated. Under SFAS&nbsp;No.&nbsp;123(R), an equity instrument is not recorded to common stockholders' equity until the related compensation
expense is recorded over the requisite service period of the award. The Company records compensation expense on a straight-line basis for awards exclusive of the Long-Term Incentive Plan
awards. Prior to the adoption of SFAS&nbsp;No.&nbsp;123(R), and in accordance with the previous accounting guidance, the Company recognized compensation expense and an increase to additional paid
in capital for the fair value of vested stock awards and stock options. In addition, the Company recognized compensation expense and a corresponding liability for the fair value of vested stock units
issued under the Eligible Directors' Deferred Compensation/Phantom Stock Plan ("Directors' Phantom Stock&nbsp;Plan"). </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>In
connection with the adoption of SFAS&nbsp;No.&nbsp;123(R), the Company determined that $6,000 included in other accrued liabilities at December&nbsp;31, 2005, in connection with the
Directors' Phantom Stock Plan, should be included in additional paid-in capital. Additionally, the Company reclassified $15,464 from the Unamortized Restricted Stock line item within
equity to additional paid-in capital. The Company made these reclassifications during the year ended December&nbsp;31,&nbsp;2006. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>2003 Equity Incentive Plan:  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>The 2003 Equity Incentive Plan ("2003 Plan") authorizes the grant of stock awards, stock options, stock appreciation rights, stock units, stock bonuses, performance based
awards, dividend equivalent rights and operating partnership units or other convertible or exchangeable units. As of December&nbsp;31, 2006, only stock awards, limited operating partnership units
and stock options have been granted under the 2003 Plan. All awards granted under the 2003 Plan have a term of 10&nbsp;years or less. These awards were generally granted based on certain
performance criteria for the Company and the employees. The aggregate number of shares of common stock that may be issued under the 2003 Plan is 6,000,000&nbsp;shares. As of December&nbsp;31,
2006, there were 5,134,664&nbsp;shares available for issuance under the 2003&nbsp;Plan. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>The
following stock awards, limited operating partnership units and stock options have been granted under the 2003&nbsp;Plan: </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>Stock
Awards </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>The
outstanding stock awards vest over three years and the compensation cost related to the grants are determined by the market value at the grant date and are amortized over the vesting period on a
straight-line </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="RIGHT"><FONT SIZE=2><I>The Macerich Company&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>101</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=4,SEQ=103,EFW="2175451",CP="THE MACERICH COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=904494,FOLIO='101',FILE='DISK132:[07BHL4.07BHL1004]FK1004A.;67',USER='GKIBBE',CD='27-FEB-2007;10:09' -->
<A NAME="page_fk1004_1_102"> </A>
<BR>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>basis.
Stock awards are subject to restrictions determined by the Company's compensation committee. Stock awards have the same dividend and voting rights as common stock. Compensation cost for stock
awards was $14,190, $11,528 and $8,394 for the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2006, 2005 and 2004, respectively. As of December&nbsp;31, 2006, there was $15,256 of total unrecognized compensation
cost related to non-vested stock awards. This cost is expected to be recognized over a weighted average period of three&nbsp;years. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>On
October&nbsp;31, 2006, as part of a separation agreement with a former executive, the Company accelerated the vesting of 34,829&nbsp;shares of stock awards. As result of the accelerated
vesting, the Company recognized an additional $610 in compensation&nbsp;cost. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Long-Term
Incentive Plan Units </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>On
October&nbsp;26, 2006, The Macerich Company 2006 Long-Term Incentive Plan ("2006 LTIP"), a long-term incentive compensation program, was approved pursuant to the 2003 Plan. Under the
2006 LTIP, each award recipient is issued a new form of limited operating partnership units ("LTIP Units") in the Operating Partnership. The LTIP Units vest over a three-year period based
on the percentile ranking of the Company in terms of total return to stockholders (the&nbsp;"Total Return") per common stock share relative to the Total Return of a group of peer REITs, as measured
at the end of each year of the measurement period. Upon the occurence of specified events and subject to the satisfaction of applicable vesting conditions, LTIP Units are ultimately redeemable for
common stock on a one-unit for one-share basis. LTIP Units receive cash dividends based on the dividend amount paid on the common stock. On October&nbsp;26, 2006, the
Company granted 215,709 LTIP Units to four executive officers at a weighted average grant date fair value of $80.04. None of the granted LTIP Units were vested at December&nbsp;31, 2006.
Compensation expense for LTIP Units was $685 for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2006. As of December&nbsp;31, 2006, there was $10,520 of unrecognized cost related to non-vested LTIP
Units, which is expected to be recognized over the three years ending December&nbsp;31,&nbsp;2009 using the graded attribution method. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>The
fair value of the Company's LTIP Units was estimated on the date of grant using a Monte Carlo Simulation model. The stock price of the Company, along with the stock prices of the group of peer
REITs, was assumed to follow the Multivariate Geometric Brownian Motion Process. Multivariate Geometric Brownian Motion is a common assumption when modeling in financial markets, as it allows the
modeled quantity (in this case, the stock price) to vary randomly from its current value and take any value greater than zero. The volatilities of the returns on the price of the Company and the peer
group REITs were estimated based on a three year look-back period. The expected growth rate of the stock prices over the three year "derived service period" were determined with consideration of the
three year risk free rate as of the grant date. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>102</FONT> <FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Macerich Company</I></FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=5,SEQ=104,EFW="2175451",CP="THE MACERICH COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=233249,FOLIO='102',FILE='DISK132:[07BHL4.07BHL1004]FK1004A.;67',USER='GKIBBE',CD='27-FEB-2007;10:09' -->
<A NAME="page_fk1004_1_103"> </A>
<BR>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Stock
Options </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>On
October&nbsp;8, 2003, the Company granted 2,500 stock options at a weighted average exercise price of $39.43. These outstanding stock options vested six months after the grant date and were
issued with a strike price equal to the fair value of the common stock at the grant date. The term of these stock options is ten years from the grant date. The Company has not issued stock options
since 2003. All outstanding stock options were fully vested as of December&nbsp;31, 2004 and therefore, were not impacted by the adoption of SFAS&nbsp;No.&nbsp;123(R). </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Total fair value of stock awards vested during the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2006, 2005 and 2004 were $23,302, $13,267 and $16,873, respectively. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Directors' Phantom Stock Plan:  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>The Directors' Phantom Stock Plan offers non-employee members of the board of directors ("Directors") the opportunity to defer their cash compensation and to
receive that compensation in common stock rather than in cash after termination of service or a predetermined period. Compensation generally includes the annual retainer and regular meeting fees
payable by the Company to the Directors. Every Director has elected to receive their compensation in common stock. Deferred amounts are credited as units of phantom stock at the beginning of </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="RIGHT"><FONT SIZE=2><I>The Macerich Company&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>103</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=6,SEQ=105,EFW="2175451",CP="THE MACERICH COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=360131,FOLIO='103',FILE='DISK132:[07BHL4.07BHL1004]FK1004A.;67',USER='GKIBBE',CD='27-FEB-2007;10:09' -->
<A NAME="page_fk1004_1_104"> </A>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>each
three-year deferral period by dividing the present value of the deferred compensation by the average fair market value of the Company's common stock at the date of award.
Compensation expense related to the phantom stock award was determined by the amortization of the value of the stock units on a straight-line basis over the applicable
three-year service period. The stock units (including dividend equivalents) vest as the Directors' services (to&nbsp;which the fees relate) are rendered. Vested phantom stock units are
ultimately paid out in common stock on a one-unit for one-share basis. Stock units receive dividend equivalents in the form of additional stock units, based on the dividend
amount paid on the common stock. Compensation expense for stock awards was $534, $1,128 and $1,750 for the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2006, 2005 and 2004, respectively. The aggregate number of
phantom stock units that may be granted under the Directors' Phantom Stock Plan is 250,000. As of December&nbsp;31, 2006, there were 131,084&nbsp;units available for grant under the Directors'
Phantom Stock Plan. As of December&nbsp;31, 2006, there was no unrecognized cost related to non-vested phantom stock&nbsp;units. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>The
following table summarizes the activity of the non-vested phantom stock&nbsp;units: </FONT></P>

<!-- User-specified TAGGED TABLE -->
<TABLE WIDTH="100%" BORDER=0 CELLSPACING=0 CELLPADDING=0>
<TR VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<TH COLSPAN=2 ALIGN="LEFT"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT><BR></TH>
<TH WIDTH="3%"><FONT SIZE=1>&nbsp;</FONT></TH>
<TH WIDTH="12%" ALIGN="RIGHT"><FONT SIZE=1><B>Number of<BR>
Shares<BR> </B></FONT><BR></TH>
<TH WIDTH="3%"><FONT SIZE=1>&nbsp;</FONT></TH>
<TH WIDTH="10%" ALIGN="RIGHT"><FONT SIZE=1><B>Weighted Average<BR>
Exercise Price<BR> </B></FONT><BR></TH>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<TH COLSPAN=6 ALIGN="CENTER"><HR NOSHADE></TH>
</TR>

<!-- end of user-specified TAGGED TABLE -->


<P><FONT SIZE=2>During 2004, the Company issued 17,862 shares of common stock at a value of $934 for an equivalent number of vested phantom stock units. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Employee Stock Purchase Plan:  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>The ESPP authorizes eligible employees to purchase the Company's common stock through voluntary payroll deduction made during periodic offering periods. Under the plan, common
stock is purchased at a 10% discount from the lesser of the fair value of common stock at the beginning and ending of the offering period. A maximum of 750,000&nbsp;shares of common stock is
available for purchase under the ESPP. The number of shares available for future purchase under the plan at December&nbsp;31, 2006 was&nbsp;732,821. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>104</FONT> <FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Macerich Company</I></FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=7,SEQ=106,EFW="2175451",CP="THE MACERICH COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=1043864,FOLIO='104',FILE='DISK132:[07BHL4.07BHL1004]FK1004A.;67',USER='GKIBBE',CD='27-FEB-2007;10:09' -->
<A NAME="page_fk1004_1_105"> </A>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Other Share-Based Plans  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Prior to the adoption of the 2003 Plan, the Company had several other share-based plans. Under these plans, 427,822&nbsp;stock options were outstanding as of
December&nbsp;31, 2006. No additional shares may be issued under these plans. All stock options outstanding under these plans were fully vested as of December&nbsp;31, 2005 and were, therefore,
not impacted by the adoption of SFAS&nbsp;No.&nbsp;123(R). As of December&nbsp;31, 2006, all of the outstanding shares are exercisable at a weighted average price of $24.07. The weighted average
remaining contractual life for options outstanding and exercisable was three&nbsp;years. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>17.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Profit Sharing Plan:  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>The Company has a retirement profit sharing plan that covers substantially all of its eligible employees. The plan is qualified in accordance with section&nbsp;401(a) of the
Internal Revenue Code. Effective January&nbsp;1, 1995, this plan was modified to include a 401(k) plan whereby employees can elect to defer compensation subject to Internal Revenue Service
withholding rules. This plan was further amended effective February&nbsp;1, 1999, to add The Macerich Company </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Common
Stock Fund as a new investment alternative under the plan. A total of 150,000&nbsp;shares of common stock were reserved for issuance under the plan. Contributions by the Company to the plan
were made at the discretion of the Board of Directors and were based upon a specified percentage of employee compensation. The Company contributed $1,694 during the year ended December&nbsp;31,
2004. On January&nbsp;1, 2004, the plan adopted the "Safe Harbor" provision under Sections&nbsp;401(k)(12) and&nbsp;401(m)(11) of the Internal Revenue Code. In accordance with these newly
adopted provisions, the Company began matching contributions equal to 100&nbsp;percent of the first three percent of compensation deferred by a participant and 50&nbsp;percent of the next two
percent of compensation deferred by a participant. During the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2006 and 2005, these matching contributions made by the Company were $1,747 and $1,984, respectively.
Contributions are recognized as compensation in the period they are&nbsp;made. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>18.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Deferred Compensation Plans:  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>The Company has established deferred compensation plans under which key executives of the Company may elect to defer receiving a portion of their cash compensation otherwise
payable in one calendar year until a later year. The Company may, as determined by the Board of Directors at its sole discretion, credit a participant's account with an amount equal to a percentage of
the participant's deferral. The Company contributed $712, $595 and $632 to the plans during the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2006, 2005 and 2004, respectively. Contributions are recognized as
compensation in the periods they are&nbsp;made. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>In
addition, certain executives have split dollar life insurance agreements with the Company whereby the Company generally pays annual premiums on a life insurance policy in an amount equal to the
executives deferral under one of the Company's deferred compensation plans. Since July&nbsp;30, 2002, the effective date of the Sarbanes-Oxley Act of 2002, the Company has not made any premium
payments on the&nbsp;policies. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="RIGHT"><FONT SIZE=2><I>The Macerich Company&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>105</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=8,SEQ=107,EFW="2175451",CP="THE MACERICH COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=839454,FOLIO='105',FILE='DISK132:[07BHL4.07BHL1004]FK1004B.;40',USER='GKIBBE',CD='27-FEB-2007;10:09' -->
<A NAME="page_fk1004_1_106"> </A>
<BR>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>19.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Income Taxes:  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>The Company elected to be taxed as a REIT under the Internal Revenue Code with its taxable year ended December&nbsp;31, 1994. To qualify as a REIT, the Company must meet a
number of organizational and operational requirements, including a requirement that it distribute at least 90% of its taxable income to its stockholders. It is management's current intention to adhere
to these requirements and maintain the Company's REIT status. As a REIT, the Company generally will not be subject to corporate level federal income tax on net income it distributes currently to its
stockholders. If the Company fails to qualify as a REIT in any taxable year, then it will be subject to federal income taxes at regular corporate rates (including any applicable alternative minimum
tax) and may not be able to qualify as a REIT for four subsequent taxable years. Even if the Company qualifies for taxation as a REIT, the Company may be subject to certain state and local taxes on
its income and property and to federal income and excise taxes on its undistributed taxable income, if&nbsp;any. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Each
partner is taxed individually on its share of partnership income or loss, and accordingly, no provision for federal and state income tax is provided for the Operating Partnership in the
consolidated financial statements. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>The
following table reconciles net income available to common stockholders to taxable income available to common stockholders for the year ended December&nbsp;31: </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>The Company has made Taxable REIT Subsidiary elections for all of its corporate subsidiaries other than its Qualified REIT Subsidiaries. The elections, effective
for the year beginning January&nbsp;1, 2001 and future years were made pursuant to section&nbsp;856(l) of the Internal Revenue Code. The Company's TRSs are subject to corporate level income taxes
which are provided for in the Company's consolidated financial statements. The Company's primary TRSs include Macerich Management Company and Westcor Partners,&nbsp;LLC. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="RIGHT"><FONT SIZE=2><I>The Macerich Company&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>107</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=10,SEQ=109,EFW="2175451",CP="THE MACERICH COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=160272,FOLIO='107',FILE='DISK132:[07BHL4.07BHL1004]FK1004B.;40',USER='GKIBBE',CD='27-FEB-2007;10:09' -->
<A NAME="page_fk1004_1_108"> </A>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>SFAS&nbsp;No.&nbsp;109 requires recognition of deferred tax assets and liabilities for the expected future tax consequences of events that have been included
in the financial statements or tax returns. Under this method, deferred tax assets and liabilities are determined based on the differences between the financial reporting and tax bases of assets and
liabilities using enacted tax rates in effect for the year in which the differences are expected to reverse. The deferred tax assets and liabilities of the TRS's relate primarily to differences in the
book and tax bases of property and to operating loss carryforwards for federal and state income tax purposes. A valuation allowance for deferred tax assets is provided if the Company believes it is
more likely than not that all or some portion of the deferred tax assets will not be realized. Realization of deferred tax assets is dependent on the Company generating sufficient taxable income in
future periods. The net operating loss carryforwards are currently scheduled to expire through 2026, beginning in&nbsp;2011. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>The
tax effects of temporary differences and carryforwards of the TRSs included in the net deferred tax assets at December&nbsp;31, 2006 and 2005 are summarized as&nbsp;follows: </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>20.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Stock Offering:  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>On January&nbsp;19, 2006, the Company issued 10,952,381 common shares for net proceeds of $746,485. The proceeds from issuance of the shares were used to pay off the $619,000
acquisition loan (See&nbsp;Note&nbsp;10 &#151;Bank and&nbsp;Other Notes Payable) and to pay down a portion of the Company's line of credit pending use to pay part of the purchase price
for Valley River Center (See&nbsp;Note&nbsp;12 &#151;Acquisitions). </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>21.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Cumulative Convertible Redeemable Preferred Stock:  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>On February&nbsp;25, 1998, the Company issued 3,627,131&nbsp;shares of Series&nbsp;A cumulative convertible redeemable preferred stock ("Series&nbsp;A Preferred Stock")
for proceeds totaling $100,000 in a private placement. The preferred stock can be converted on a one for one basis into common stock and will pay a quarterly dividend equal to the greater of $0.46 per
share, or the dividend then payable on a share of common&nbsp;stock. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>No
dividends will be declared or paid on any class of common or other junior stock to the extent that dividends on Series&nbsp;A Preferred Stock have not been declared and/or&nbsp;paid. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>The
holders of Series&nbsp;A Preferred Stock have redemption rights if a change in control of the Company occurs, as defined under the Articles Supplementary. Under such circumstances, the holders
of the Series&nbsp;A Preferred Stock </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>108</FONT> <FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Macerich Company</I></FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=11,SEQ=110,EFW="2175451",CP="THE MACERICH COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=993414,FOLIO='108',FILE='DISK132:[07BHL4.07BHL1004]FK1004B.;40',USER='GKIBBE',CD='27-FEB-2007;10:09' -->
<A NAME="page_fk1004_1_109"> </A>
<BR>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>are
entitled to require the Company to redeem their shares, to the extent the Company has funds legally available therefor, at a price equal to 105% of its liquidation preference plus accrued and
unpaid dividends. The Series&nbsp;A Preferred Stock holder also has the right to require the Company to repurchase its shares if the Company fails to be taxed as a REIT for federal tax purposes at a
price equal to 115% of its liquidation preference plus accrued and unpaid dividends, to the extent funds are legally available therefor. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>22.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Segment Information:  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>SFAS&nbsp;No.&nbsp;131, "Disclosures about Segments of an Enterprise and Related Information," established standards for disclosure about operating segments and related
disclosures about products and services, geographic areas and major customers. The Company currently operates in one business segment, the acquisition, ownership, development, redevelopment,
management and leasing of regional and community shopping centers. Additionally, the Company operates in one geographic area, the United&nbsp;States. </FONT></P>

<DL compact>
<DT style='margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(1)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> Revenues as reported in the Company's Form&nbsp;10-Q's have been reclassified to reflect SFAS&nbsp;No.&nbsp;144 for&nbsp;discontinued
operations.</I></FONT></DD></DL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>24.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Subsequent Events:  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>On February&nbsp;9, 2007, the Company declared a dividend/distribution of $0.71 per share for common stockholders and OP Unit holders of record on February&nbsp;23, 2007. In
addition, the Company declared a dividend of $0.71 on the Company's Series&nbsp;A Preferred Stock. On February&nbsp;9, 2007, MACWH, LP declared a distribution of $0.96 per unit for its convertible
preferred unit holders and $0.71 per unit for its common unit holders of record on February&nbsp;23, 2007. All dividends/distributions will be payable on March&nbsp;8,&nbsp;2007. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="fm1004_reports_of_independent___fm102396"> </A>
<A NAME="toc_fm1004_1"> </A>
<BR></FONT><FONT SIZE=2><B>REPORTS OF INDEPENDENT REGISTERED PUBLIC ACCOUNTING FIRMS    <BR>    </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>To
the Board of Trustees and Stockholders of<BR>
Pacific Premier Retail Trust </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>We
have audited the accompanying consolidated balance sheets of Pacific Premier Retail Trust, a Maryland Real Estate Investment Trust (the&nbsp;"Trust") as of December&nbsp;31, 2006 and 2005, and
the related consolidated statements of operations, stockholders' equity, and cash flows for each of the three years in the period ended December&nbsp;31, 2006. Our audits also included the
consolidated financial statement schedule listed in the Index at Item&nbsp;15(a)(4), as of and for the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2006, 2005 and 2004. These consolidated financial statements
and the consolidated financial statement schedules are the responsibility of the Trust's management. Our responsibility is to express an opinion on these consolidated financial statements and the
consolidated financial statement schedules based on our&nbsp;audits. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>We
conducted our audits in accordance with auditing standards generally accepted in the United&nbsp;States of America and in accordance with the standards of the Public Company Accounting Oversight
Board (United&nbsp;States). Those standards require that we plan and perform the audits to obtain reasonable assurance about whether the financial statements are free of material misstatement. The
Trust is not required to have, nor were we engaged to perform, an audit of its internal control over financial reporting. Our audits included consideration of internal control over financial
reporting as a basis for designing audit procedures that are appropriate in the circumstances, but not for the purpose of expressing an opinion on the effectiveness of the Trust's internal control
over financial reporting. Accordingly, we express no such opinion. An audit also includes examining, on a test basis, evidence supporting the amounts and disclosures in the financial statements,
assessing the accounting principles used and significant estimates made by management, as well as evaluating the overall financial statement presentation. We believe that our audits provide a
reasonable basis for our&nbsp;opinion. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>In
our opinion, such 2006, 2005 and 2004 financial statements present fairly, in all material respects, the financial position of the Trust as of December&nbsp;31, 2006 and 2005, and the results of
its operations and its cash flows for each of the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2006 in conformity with accounting principles generally accepted in the United&nbsp;States of America. Also, in our
opinion, based on our audits the consolidated financial statement schedules as of and for the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2006, 2005 and 2004, when considered in relation to the basic
consolidated financial statements taken as a whole, present fairly, in all material respects, the information set forth&nbsp;therein. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Deloitte&nbsp;&amp;
Touche&nbsp;LLP<BR>
Los Angeles, California<BR>
February 27, 2007 </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>110</FONT> <FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Macerich Company</I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="page_fs1004_1_115"> </A> </FONT>
<BR><FONT SIZE=2><B>PACIFIC PREMIER RETAIL TRUST  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B> NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B> (Dollars in thousands, except per share amounts)  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>1.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Organization and Basis of Presentation:  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>On February&nbsp;18, 1999, Macerich PPR Corp. (the "Corp"), an indirect wholly-owned subsidiary of The Macerich Company (the "Company"), and Ontario Teachers' Pension Plan
Board ("Ontario Teachers") formed the Pacific Premier Retail Trust (the "Trust") to acquire and operate a portfolio of regional shopping centers ("Centers"). </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Included
in the Centers is a 99% interest in Los Cerritos Center and Stonewood Mall, all other Centers are held at&nbsp;100%. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>The
Centers as of December&nbsp;31, 2006 and their locations are as follows: </FONT></P>

<!-- end of user-specified TAGGED TABLE -->


<P><FONT SIZE=2>The Trust was organized to qualify as a real estate investment trust ("REIT") under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, as amended. The Corp maintains a 51% ownership interest
in the Trust, while Ontario Teachers' maintains a 49% ownership interest in the&nbsp;Trust. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>2.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Summary of Significant Accounting Policies:  </B></FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Cash and Cash Equivalents:  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>The Trust considers all highly liquid investments with an original maturity of three months or less when purchased to be cash equivalents, for which cost approximates
fair&nbsp;value. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Tenant Receivables:  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Included in tenant receivables are accrued percentage rents of $2,540 and $3,097 and an allowance for doubtful accounts of $442 and $392 at December&nbsp;31, 2006 and 2005,
respectively. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="RIGHT"><FONT SIZE=2><I>The Macerich Company&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>115</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=1,SEQ=117,EFW="2175451",CP="THE MACERICH COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=714576,FOLIO='115',FILE='DISK132:[07BHL4.07BHL1004]FS1004A.;18',USER='GKIBBE',CD='27-FEB-2007;12:55' -->
<A NAME="page_fs1004_1_116"> </A>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Revenues:  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Minimum rental revenues are recognized on a straight-line basis over the terms of the related lease. The difference between the amount of rent due in a year and the
amount recorded as rental income is referred to as the "straight-lining of rent adjustment." Rental income was increased (decreased) by $104, $200 and ($138) in 2006, 2005 and 2004, respectively, due
to the straight-lining of rents. Percentage rents are recognized on an accrual basis and are accrued when tenants' specified sales targets have been&nbsp;met. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>Estimated
recoveries from tenants for real estate taxes, insurance and other shopping center operating expenses are recognized as revenues in the period the applicable expenses are incurred or as
specified in the&nbsp;leases. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Property:  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Costs related to the redevelopment, construction and improvement of properties are capitalized. Interest incurred or imputed on redevelopment and construction projects is
capitalized until construction is substantially complete. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Maintenance
and repairs expenses are charged to operations as incurred. Costs for major replacements and betterments, which includes HVAC equipment, roofs, parking lots, etc. are capitalized and
depreciated over their estimated useful lives. Gains and losses are recognized upon disposal or retirement of the related assets and are reflected in&nbsp;earnings. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Property
is recorded at cost and is depreciated using a straight-line method over the estimated lives of the assets as&nbsp;follows: </FONT></P>

<!-- User-specified TAGGED TABLE -->
<TABLE WIDTH="100%" BORDER=0 CELLSPACING=0 CELLPADDING=0>
<TR VALIGN="TOP">
<TD COLSPAN=3><HR NOSHADE></TD>
</TR>
<TR BGCOLOR="#CCEEFF" VALIGN="TOP">
<TD WIDTH="49%"><FONT SIZE=2>Building and improvements</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="49%" ALIGN="RIGHT"><FONT SIZE=2>5-39&nbsp;years</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR BGCOLOR="White" VALIGN="TOP">
<TD WIDTH="49%"><FONT SIZE=2>Tenant improvements</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="49%" ALIGN="RIGHT"><FONT SIZE=2>5-7&nbsp;years</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR BGCOLOR="#CCEEFF" VALIGN="TOP">
<TD WIDTH="49%"><FONT SIZE=2>Equipment and furnishings</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="49%" ALIGN="RIGHT"><FONT SIZE=2>5-7&nbsp;years</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="TOP">
<TD COLSPAN=3><HR NOSHADE></TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<!-- end of user-specified TAGGED TABLE -->


<P><FONT SIZE=2>The Trust assesses whether there has been impairment in the value of its long-lived assets by considering expected future operating income, trends and prospects, as
well as the effects of demand, competition and other economic factors. Such factors include the tenants' ability to perform their duties and pay rent under the terms of the leases. The determination
of recoverability is made based upon the estimated undiscounted future net cash flows, excluding interest expense. The amount of impairment loss, if any, is determined by comparing the fair value, as
determined by a undiscounted cash flows analysis, with the carrying value of the related assets. Long-lived assets classified as held for sale are measured at the lower of the carrying
amount or fair value less cost to sell. Management does not believe impairment has occurred in its net property carrying values at December&nbsp;31, 2006 or&nbsp;2005. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>116</FONT> <FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Macerich Company</I></FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=2,SEQ=118,EFW="2175451",CP="THE MACERICH COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=298721,FOLIO='116',FILE='DISK132:[07BHL4.07BHL1004]FS1004A.;18',USER='GKIBBE',CD='27-FEB-2007;12:55' -->
<A NAME="page_fs1004_1_117"> </A>
<BR>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Deferred Charges:  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Costs relating to obtaining tenant leases are deferred and amortized over the initial term of the agreement using the straight-line method. Costs relating to
financing of properties are deferred and amortized over the life of the related loan using the straight-line method, which approximates the effective interest method. The range of terms
of the agreements is as&nbsp;follows: </FONT></P>

<!-- User-specified TAGGED TABLE -->
<TABLE WIDTH="100%" BORDER=0 CELLSPACING=0 CELLPADDING=0>
<TR VALIGN="TOP">
<TD COLSPAN=3><HR NOSHADE></TD>
</TR>
<TR BGCOLOR="#CCEEFF" VALIGN="TOP">
<TD WIDTH="49%"><FONT SIZE=2>Deferred lease cost</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="49%" ALIGN="RIGHT"><FONT SIZE=2>1-9&nbsp;years</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR BGCOLOR="White" VALIGN="TOP">
<TD WIDTH="49%"><FONT SIZE=2>Deferred finance costs</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="49%" ALIGN="RIGHT"><FONT SIZE=2>1-12&nbsp;years</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="TOP">
<TD COLSPAN=3><HR NOSHADE></TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<!-- end of user-specified TAGGED TABLE -->


<P><FONT SIZE=2>Included in deferred charges are accumulated amortization of $12,209 and $9,266 at December&nbsp;31, 2006 and 2005, respectively. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Fair Value of Financial Instruments  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>The Trust calculates the fair value of financial instruments and includes this additional information in the notes to consolidated financial statements when the fair value is
different than the carrying value of those financial instruments. When the fair value reasonably approximates the carrying value, no additional disclosure is made. The estimated fair value amounts
have been determined by the Trust using available market information and appropriate valuation methodologies. However, considerable judgment is required in interpreting market data to develop the
estimates of fair value. Accordingly, the estimates presented herein are not necessarily indicative of the amounts that the Trust could realize in a current market exchange. The use of different
market assumptions and/or estimation methodologies may have a material effect on the estimated fair value&nbsp;amounts. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Concentration of Risk:  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>The Trust maintains its cash accounts in a number of commercial banks. Accounts at these banks are guaranteed by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation ("FDIC") up to $100.
At various times during the year, the Trust had deposits in excess of the FDIC insurance limit. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>One
tenant represented 10.6%, 10.7% and 11.4% of total minimum rents in place as of December&nbsp;31, 2006, 2005 and 2004, respectively. No other tenant represented more than 10% of total minimum
rents as of December&nbsp;31, 2006, 2005 and 2004. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Management Estimates:  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>The preparation of financial statements in conformity with GAAP requires management to make estimates and assumptions that affect the reported amounts of assets and liabilities
and disclosure of contingent assets and liabilities at the date of the financial statements and the reported amounts of revenues and expenses during the reporting period. Actual results could differ
from those estimates. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="RIGHT"><FONT SIZE=2><I>The Macerich Company&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>117</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=3,SEQ=119,EFW="2175451",CP="THE MACERICH COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=841221,FOLIO='117',FILE='DISK132:[07BHL4.07BHL1004]FS1004A.;18',USER='GKIBBE',CD='27-FEB-2007;12:55' -->
<A NAME="page_fs1004_1_118"> </A>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Recent Accounting Pronouncements:  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>In December&nbsp;2004, the Financial Accounting Standards Board ("FASB") issued Statement of Financial Accounting Standards ("SFAS") No.&nbsp;123 (revised), "Share-Based
Payment" SFAS&nbsp;No.&nbsp;123(R) requires that all share-based payments to employees, including grants of employee stock options, be recognized in the income statement based on their fair
values. The adoption of this statement did not have a material effect on the results of&nbsp;operations. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>In
March&nbsp;2005, FASB issued FIN&nbsp;No.&nbsp;47, "Accounting for&nbsp;Conditional Asset Retirement Obligations &#151;an interpretation of SFAS&nbsp;No.&nbsp;143."
FIN&nbsp;No.&nbsp;47, requires that a liability be recognized for the fair value of a conditional asset retirement obligation if the fair value can be reasonably estimated. The adoption of
FIN&nbsp;No.&nbsp;47 did not have a material effect on the Trust's results of operations or financial condition. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>In
June&nbsp;2006, the FASB issued Interpretation No.&nbsp;48, "Accounting for&nbsp;Uncertainty in Income Taxes &#151;an interpretation of FASB Statement No.&nbsp;109"
("FIN&nbsp;48"). This interpretation clarifies the accounting for uncertainty in income taxes recognized in an enterprise's financial statements in accordance with SFAS&nbsp;No.&nbsp;109,
"Accounting for&nbsp;Income Taxes." This Interpretation prescribes a recognition threshold and measurement attribute for the financial statement recognition and measurement of a tax position taken
or expected to be taken in a tax return. This Interpretation also provides guidance on derecognition of previously recognized income tax benefits, classification, interest and penalties, accounting
in interim periods, disclosure, and transition. FIN&nbsp;48 is effective for fiscal years beginning after December&nbsp;15, 2006. The Trust has concluded that the adoption of FIN&nbsp;48 will
not have a material impact on its financial statements. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>In
September&nbsp;2006, the FASB issued SFAS&nbsp;No.&nbsp;157, "Fair Value Measurements." SFAS&nbsp;No.&nbsp;157 defines fair value, establishes a framework for measuring fair value, and
expands disclosures about fair value measurements. The Company is required to adopt SFAS&nbsp;No.&nbsp;157 for&nbsp;fiscal year 2008 and does not expect its adoption to have a material effect
on the Trust's results of operations or financial condition. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>In
September&nbsp;2006, the Securities and Exchange Commission issued Staff Accounting Bulletin ("SAB") No.&nbsp;108. SAB&nbsp;No.&nbsp;108 establishes a framework for quantifying materiality
of financial statement misstatements. SAB&nbsp;No.&nbsp;108 is effective for fiscal years ending after November&nbsp;16, 2006. The adoption of SAB&nbsp;No.&nbsp;108 did not have a material
impact on the Trust's consolidated results of operations and financial condition. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>In
February&nbsp;2006, the FASB issued SFAS&nbsp;No.&nbsp;155, "Accounting for&nbsp;Certain Hybrid Financial Instruments &#151;An Amendment of FASB Statements No.&nbsp;133
and&nbsp;140." This statement amended SFAS&nbsp;No.&nbsp;133, "Accounting for&nbsp;Derivative Instruments and Hedging Activities," and No.&nbsp;140, "Accounting for&nbsp;Transfers and
Servicing of Financial Assets and Extinguishments of Liabilities." SFAS&nbsp;No.&nbsp;155 permits fair value remeasurement for any hybrid financial instrument that contains an embedded derivative
that otherwise would require bifurcation. This statement also established a requirement to evaluate interests in securitized financial assets to identify interests </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>118</FONT> <FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Macerich Company</I></FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=4,SEQ=120,EFW="2175451",CP="THE MACERICH COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=300229,FOLIO='118',FILE='DISK132:[07BHL4.07BHL1004]FS1004A.;18',USER='GKIBBE',CD='27-FEB-2007;12:55' -->
<A NAME="page_fs1004_1_119"> </A>
<BR>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>that
are freestanding derivatives or that are hybrid financial instruments that contain an embedded derivative requiring bifurcation. The Trust is required to adopt SFAS&nbsp;No.&nbsp;155
for&nbsp;fiscal year 2007 and does not expect its adoption to have a material effect on the its results of operations or financial condition. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="RIGHT"><FONT SIZE=2><I>The Macerich Company&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>119</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=5,SEQ=121,EFW="2175451",CP="THE MACERICH COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=18688,FOLIO='119',FILE='DISK132:[07BHL4.07BHL1004]FS1004B.;18',USER='GKIBBE',CD='27-FEB-2007;12:55' -->
<A NAME="page_fs1004_1_120"> </A>
<DL compact>
<DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2><I>(a)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2><I> This represents the monthly payment of principal and interest.
<BR><BR> </I></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2><I>(b)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2><I> This debt is cross-collateralized by Kitsap Mall and Kitsap Place.
<BR><BR> </I></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2><I>(c)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2><I> On May&nbsp;20, 2006, the joint venture replaced the existing loan with a new $130,000 loan bearing interest at LIBOR plus 0.55% that matures on July&nbsp;1, 2011.
The loan
provides for additional borrowings of up to $70,000 during the four year period following the initial funding at a rate of LIBOR plus 0.90%. At December&nbsp;31, 2006, the total interest rate
was&nbsp;5.91%.
<BR><BR> </I></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2><I>(d)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2><I> This loan bears interest at LIBOR plus 2.00% and matures February&nbsp;1, 2009. At December&nbsp;31, 2006 and 2005, the total interest rate was 7.35% and 6.25%,
respectively.  </I></FONT></DD></DL>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>Most of the mortgage loan agreements contain a prepayment penalty provision for the early extinguishment of the&nbsp;debt. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Total
interest costs capitalized for the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2006, 2005 and 2004 were $668, $942 and $332, respectively. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>The
fair value of mortgage notes payable at December&nbsp;31, 2006 and 2005 was estimated to be approximately $839,711 and $846,335, based on interest rates for comparable loans. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>The
above debt matures as follows: </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>5.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Related Party Transactions:  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>The Trust engages the Macerich Management Company (the&nbsp;"Management Company"), a subsidiary of the Company, to manage the operations of the Trust. The Management Company
provides property management, leasing, corporate, redevelopment and acquisitions services to the properties of the Trust. Under these arrangements, the Management Company is reimbursed for
compensation paid to on-site employees, leasing agents and project managers at the properties, as well as insurance costs and other administrative expenses. In </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>120</FONT> <FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Macerich Company</I></FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=6,SEQ=122,EFW="2175451",CP="THE MACERICH COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=117150,FOLIO='120',FILE='DISK132:[07BHL4.07BHL1004]FS1004B.;18',USER='GKIBBE',CD='27-FEB-2007;12:55' -->
<A NAME="page_fs1004_1_121"> </A>
<BR>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>consideration
of these services, the Management Company receives monthly management fees of 4.0% of the gross monthly rental revenue of the properties. During the years ended 2006, 2005 and 2004, the
Trust incurred management fees of $6,382, $6,005 and $5,779, respectively, to the Management Company. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>A
mortgage note collateralized by the office component of Redmond Town Center is held by one of the Company's joint venture partners. In connection with this note, interest expense was $4,875, $5,125
and $5,361 during the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2006, 2005 and 2004, respectively. Additionally, no interest costs were capitalized during the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2006, 2005 and
2004, respectively, in relation to this&nbsp;note. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>6.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Income taxes:  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>The Trust elected to be taxed as a REIT under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, as amended, commencing with its taxable year ended December&nbsp;31, 1999. To qualify as a
REIT, the Trust must meet a number of organizational and operational requirements, including a requirement that it distribute at least 90% of its taxable income to its stockholders. It is the Trust's
current intention to adhere to these requirements and maintain the Trust's REIT status. As a REIT, the Trust generally will not be subject to corporate level federal income tax on net income it
distributes currently to its stockholders. As such, no provision for federal income taxes has been included in the accompanying consolidated financial statements. If the Trust fails to qualify as a
REIT in any taxable year, then it will be subject to federal income taxes at regular corporate rates (including any applicable alternative minimum tax) and may not be able to qualify as a REIT for
four subsequent taxable years. Even if the Trust qualifies for taxation as a REIT,&nbsp;the Trust may be subject to certain state and local taxes on its income and property and to federal income
and excise taxes on its undistributed taxable income, if&nbsp;any. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>The
following table reconciles net income to taxable income for the years ended December&nbsp;31: </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>8.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Redeemable Preferred Stock:  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>On October&nbsp;6, 1999, the Trust issued 125&nbsp;shares of Redeemable Preferred Shares of Beneficial Interest ("Preferred Stock") for proceeds totaling $500 in a private
placement. On October&nbsp;26, 1999, the Trust issued 254 and 246&nbsp;shares of Preferred Stock to the Corp and Ontario Teachers', respectively. The Preferred Stock can be redeemed by the Trust
at any time with 15&nbsp;days notice for $4,000 per share plus accumulated and unpaid dividends and the applicable redemption premium. The Preferred Stock will pay a semiannual dividend equal to
$300 per share. The Preferred Stock has limited voting&nbsp;rights. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>9.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Commitments:  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>The Trust has certain properties subject to non-cancelable operating ground leases. The leases expire at various times through 2069, subject in some cases to
options to extend the terms of the lease. Ground rent expense, net of amounts capitalized, was $1,425, $1,811 and $1,309 for the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2006, 2005 and 2004, respectively. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>122</FONT> <FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Macerich Company</I></FONT></P>

<!-- ZEQ.=9,SEQ=125,EFW="2175451",CP="THE MACERICH COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=779547,FOLIO='123',FILE='DISK132:[07BHL4.07BHL1004]FS1004B.;18',USER='GKIBBE',CD='27-FEB-2007;12:55' -->

<P><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="page_fu1004_1_124"> </A> </FONT></P>

<!-- TOC_END -->

<P><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="fu1004_report_of_independent_r__fu102304"> </A>
<A NAME="toc_fu1004_1"> </A>
<BR></FONT><FONT SIZE=2><B>REPORT OF INDEPENDENT REGISTERED PUBLIC ACCOUNTING FIRM    <BR>    </B></FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>The
Partners<BR>
SDG Macerich Properties,&nbsp;L.P.: </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>We
have audited the accompanying balance sheets of SDG Macerich Properties,&nbsp;L.P. as of December&nbsp;31, 2006 and 2005, and the related statements of operations, cash flows, and partners'
equity for each of the years in the three-year period ended December&nbsp;31, 2006. In connection with our audits of the financial statements, we have also audited the related financial
statement schedule (Schedule&nbsp;III). These financial statements and the financial statement schedule are the responsibility of the Partnership's management. Our responsibility is to express an
opinion on these financial statements and financial statement schedule based on our&nbsp;audits. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>We
conducted our audits in accordance with the standards of the Public Company Accounting Oversight Board (United&nbsp;States). Those standards require that we plan and perform the audit to obtain
reasonable assurance about whether the financial statements are free of material misstatement. An audit includes examining, on a test basis, evidence supporting the amounts and disclosures in the
financial statements. An audit also includes assessing the accounting principles used and significant estimates made by management, as well as evaluating the overall financial statement presentation.
We believe that our audits provide a reasonable basis for our&nbsp;opinion. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>In
our opinion, the financial statements referred to above present fairly, in all material respects, the financial position of SDG Macerich Properties,&nbsp;L.P. as of December&nbsp;31, 2006 and
2005, and the results of its operations and its cash flows for each of the years in the three-year period ended December&nbsp;31, 2006, in conformity
with U.S.&nbsp;generally accepted accounting principles. Also, in our opinion, the related financial statement schedule (Schedule&nbsp;III), when considered in relation to the basic financial
statements taken as a whole, presents fairly, in all material respects, the information set forth&nbsp;therein. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>KPMG
LLP </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Indianapolis,
Indiana<BR>
February&nbsp;27, 2007 </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>124</FONT> <FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Macerich Company</I></FONT></P>

<P><BR><FONT SIZE=2><B>SDG MACERICH PROPERTIES,&nbsp;L.P.  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B> STATEMENTS OF PARTNERS EQUITY  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>128</FONT> <FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Macerich Company</I></FONT></P>
